para_meditar.texto: But ye are not in the flesh, but in the Spirit, if so be that the Spirit of God dwell in you. Now if any man have not the Spirit of Christ, he is none of his.
But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, Meekness, temperance: against such there is no law.

But ye shall receive power, after that the Holy Ghost is come upon you: and ye shall be witnesses unto me both in Jerusalem, and in all Judaea, and in Samaria, and unto the uttermost part of the earth.

2026-08-31.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the promise of the Holy Spirit. Thank You that Your departure was necessary for the Comforter to come. We acknowledge that we often struggle to understand Your ways, but we trust in Your wisdom and love. We pray for a greater awareness of the Holy Spirit's presence in our lives. Help us to be sensitive to His leading, to be convicted by His truth, and to be empowered by His gifts. May we be filled with His love, joy, and peace, allowing Him to transform us into the image of Christ. Grant us the courage to share the Gospel, knowing that the Holy Spirit will work in the hearts of those who hear. We ask for discernment and wisdom as we navigate the world, relying on the Spirit's guidance. Strengthen our faith and deepen our relationship with You, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-01.versiculo: John 10:27-28 KJV: "My sheep hear my voice, and I know them, and they follow me: And I give unto them eternal life; and they shall never perish, neither shall any man pluck them out of my hand."
2026-09-01.reflexion: Today's passage from John 10:27-28 offers a profound comfort and assurance to believers. Jesus, the Good Shepherd, speaks of His intimate relationship with His sheep.  He declares, "My sheep hear my voice."  This highlights the importance of listening to and recognizing the voice of Christ through His Word, the Holy Spirit, and the counsel of godly people.  It's a call to be attuned to His guidance and to actively seek His will in our lives.  Jesus then emphasizes the personal nature of this relationship: "I know them, and they follow me."  This isn't just about general knowledge, but a deep, intimate understanding.  He knows our hearts, our struggles, and our needs.  The greatest promise, however, is the gift of eternal life.  Jesus assures us, "I give unto them eternal life; and they shall never perish." This is the cornerstone of our faith, the guarantee of salvation that comes through believing in Him.  Furthermore, He assures us that no one can snatch us from His hand.  We are safe, secure, and eternally protected.  This is a powerful message of hope, reminding us of the unwavering love and protection of our Shepherd.

para_meditar.texto: The Lord is my shepherd; I shall not want.

For I am persuaded, that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor powers, nor things present, nor things to come, Nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature, shall be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord.
Let your conversation be without covetousness; and be content with such things as ye have: for he hath said, I will never leave thee, nor forsake thee.

2026-09-01.oracion: Dear Lord, thank you for being our Good Shepherd. Thank you for the promise of eternal life and for the assurance that we are safe in Your loving hands. Help us to hear Your voice daily, to follow Your guidance, and to trust in Your unwavering protection.  We acknowledge our dependence on You and ask for Your grace to live a life that honors You.  Strengthen our faith and deepen our relationship with You.  Help us to remember that we are never alone, and that Your love surrounds us.  We pray for those who are struggling, that they may find comfort and hope in Your promises.  We commit our lives to You and ask for Your guidance in all things.  In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-02.versiculo: Philippians 4:7 KJV: "And the peace of God, which passeth all understanding, shall keep your hearts and minds through Christ Jesus."
2026-09-02.reflexion: Philippians 4:7 offers a profound promise: the peace of God, surpassing all human comprehension, will guard our hearts and minds in Christ Jesus. This peace isn't merely the absence of conflict; it's a deep, abiding tranquility that transcends the storms of life. It's a supernatural gift, a divine sentinel that stands watch over our inner being. The verse highlights two crucial elements: the source and the beneficiaries. The source is God, and the beneficiary is those who are 'in Christ Jesus.' This peace isn't available to everyone; it's a privilege of those who have placed their faith in Him.  It's a peace that 'passeth all understanding' – meaning it's beyond our ability to fully grasp.  This is important because it means we don't need to understand how it works to experience it.  We simply need to trust in God and His promises. When we are anxious, worried, or overwhelmed, the peace of God is available to us. This peace is a tangible reality, a shield against the anxieties that plague our world. By focusing our minds on Christ and relying on His strength, we can experience this incredible peace, even in the midst of trials and tribulations. This peace is a promise, and it is accessible to us through faith and obedience.

para_meditar.texto: Thou wilt keep him in perfect peace, whose mind is stayed on thee: because he trusteth in thee.
Peace I leave with you, my peace I give unto you: not as the world giveth, give I unto you. Let not your heart be troubled, neither let it be afraid.
Now the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace in believing, that ye may abound in hope, through the power of the Holy Ghost.

2026-09-02.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before You today, seeking Your peace that surpasses all understanding. I acknowledge my struggles with worry and anxiety, and I lay them at Your feet. I ask that You would guard my heart and mind through Christ Jesus, allowing Your peace to flood my soul. Help me to focus on You, to trust in Your promises, and to remember that You are always with me. Grant me the strength to resist the temptations to worry and to embrace the peace that comes from knowing You. Fill me with Your joy and hope, and enable me to share Your peace with others. Thank you for your unwavering love and protection, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-03.versiculo: Philippians 2:14 KJV: "Do all things without murmurings and disputings:"
2026-09-03.reflexion: Today's verse from Philippians 2:14 challenges us to live a life of genuine contentment, free from grumbling and arguing. It's a call to action, urging us to perform all our duties, both great and small, with a spirit of grace and thankfulness. The Apostle Paul, writing from prison, understood the power of a positive attitude. He knew that murmuring and disputing not only poison our own spirits but also hinder our witness for Christ. They create divisions within the body of believers and detract from the glory of God. Instead of focusing on what we lack or what we perceive as unfair, we are called to embrace a posture of gratitude. This doesn't mean ignoring injustice or difficult situations. It means approaching them with faith, knowing that God is in control and working all things for our good. It's about trusting in His plan, even when we don't understand it. This verse is a reminder that our actions speak louder than words. When we choose to obey God's commands without complaining, we demonstrate the transformative power of the gospel in our lives. It’s in these moments of quiet obedience and thankful service that we truly reflect the character of Christ.

para_meditar.texto: Use hospitality one to another without grudging.
Neither murmur ye, as some of them also murmured, and were destroyed of the destroyer.
Enter into his gates with thanksgiving, and into his courts with praise: be thankful unto him, and bless his name.

2026-09-03.oracion: Heavenly Father, I confess that I often find myself grumbling and disputing, focusing on the negatives rather than the blessings in my life. Forgive me for my complaining spirit and help me to cultivate an attitude of gratitude. Grant me the grace to perform all my duties without murmuring, knowing that you are with me and working all things for my good. Help me to trust in your plan, even when I don't understand it. Fill me with your peace and joy, so that I may be a light to others and a reflection of your love. Give me the strength to overcome the temptation to complain and help me to embrace a spirit of thankfulness in all circumstances. I pray for a heart that is always ready to give thanks and praise to you. In Jesus' name, amen.

2026-09-04.versiculo: 1 Thessalonians 3:12 KJV: "And the Lord make you to increase and abound in love one toward another, and toward all men, even as we do toward you:"
2026-09-04.reflexion:
Today's verse, 1 Thessalonians 3:12, is a beautiful prayer for the Thessalonians, and by extension, for us. Paul prays that the Lord would cause them to "increase and abound in love." This isn't just a passive wish; it's a call to action, a challenge to actively cultivate love in our lives. The love Paul speaks of is not merely a feeling, but a deliberate choice, a willingness to serve, forgive, and cherish others. It is a love that mirrors the love Christ has for us.

The verse highlights two crucial dimensions of love: love for one another within the community of believers and love for all men. This outward focus reminds us that our faith isn't confined to the walls of a church or the privacy of our hearts. It is meant to spill over, transforming our interactions with everyone we encounter. We are called to love even those who are difficult, those who may not share our beliefs, and those who may have wronged us. This type of love is only possible through the power of the Holy Spirit working in us, enabling us to live out the very essence of Christ's teachings.

As we reflect on this verse, let us examine our own hearts. Are we increasing and abounding in love? Are we willing to extend grace and compassion to others? Let us ask God to fill us with His love, so that we may truly reflect His image to the world.

para_meditar.texto: A new commandment I give unto you, That ye love one another; as I have loved you, that ye also love one another.
Charity suffereth long, and is kind; charity envieth not; charity vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up,
Be kindly affectioned one to another with brotherly love; in honour preferring one another;

2026-09-04.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with hearts full of gratitude for your boundless love. We thank you for the example of Jesus Christ, who demonstrated perfect love and sacrifice for us. Lord, we pray that you would fill us with your Holy Spirit, empowering us to increase and abound in love, as Paul prayed for the Thessalonians. Help us to love one another within the body of Christ, supporting, encouraging, and forgiving each other. Grant us the grace to love all people, even those who are difficult or different from us. Give us the courage to show compassion, mercy, and kindness in all our interactions. May our lives be a reflection of your love, drawing others to you. Guide us in our daily walk, that we may glorify your name in all we do. We ask this in the precious name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-05.versiculo: Luke 13:24 KJV: "Strive to enter in at the strait gate: for many, I say unto you, will seek to enter in, and shall not be able."
2026-09-05.reflexion: The words of Jesus in Luke 13:24 are a stark warning, a call to fervent action. He urges us to 'strive' – a word implying intense effort, a struggle, a pushing through – to enter the 'strait gate.' This gate, representing the path to salvation and eternal life, is not easily found or entered. It requires diligence, determination, and a conscious choice to forsake the broader, more comfortable path that leads to destruction. The verse also reveals a sobering truth: many will try, but will fail. They may seek, perhaps even earnestly, but their efforts will be in vain. This is not because God is unwilling, but because they do not commit fully to the rigorous pursuit of faith and obedience. They may be content with a superficial relationship with God, or they may cling to worldly desires that hinder their progress. The challenge lies in recognizing the narrowness of the path and the necessity of dedicating ourselves wholeheartedly to the journey. We must examine our lives, identifying and renouncing the things that obstruct our passage through the gate. This is a call to a life of faith, repentance, and unwavering commitment to Christ.

para_meditar.texto: Enter ye in at the strait gate: for wide is the gate, and broad is the way, that leadeth to destruction, and many there be which go in thereat: Because strait is the gate, and narrow is the way, which leadeth unto life, and few there be that find it.

Wherefore seeing we also are compassed about with so great a cloud of witnesses, let us lay aside every weight, and the sin which doth so easily beset us, and let us run with patience the race that is set before us,
I press toward the mark for the prize of the high calling of God in Christ Jesus.

2026-09-05.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before You today with a heart that seeks to understand and embrace the challenge of Luke 13:24. Help me to recognize the 'strait gate' and to commit myself wholeheartedly to the path that leads to eternal life. Grant me the strength to 'strive,' to push past the distractions and temptations that seek to hinder my progress. Help me to lay aside every weight and the sin that so easily entangles me. Fill me with a fervent desire for You, a hunger for Your Word, and a willingness to obey Your commands. Guide me to examine my heart and identify any areas where I am not fully committed. Give me the courage to make the necessary changes, to walk the narrow path, and to persevere until the end. Thank you for Your grace, Your mercy, and Your unwavering love. I pray this, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-06.versiculo: John 3:30 KJV: "He must increase, but I must decrease."
2026-09-06.reflexion: This verse, spoken by John the Baptist, is a powerful statement of humility and selflessness. It reveals the profound understanding John had of his own role in God's plan. He recognized that his purpose was to point people to Jesus, the Messiah, and that as Jesus' ministry flourished, his own would naturally diminish. John understood that true fulfillment comes not from personal glory or recognition, but from the increase of Christ in the lives of others. This challenges us to examine our own hearts. Are we willing to decrease, to step aside, to allow Jesus to take center stage in our lives and the lives of those around us? It requires a deliberate choice to prioritize God's will above our own desires and ambitions. It means embracing humility and recognizing that we are merely instruments in God's grand design. John's words are a call to selflessness, a reminder that true joy comes from seeing Christ glorified and His Kingdom advanced. We must strive to be like John, constantly pointing others to Jesus, allowing Him to increase in influence and power, and willingly diminishing ourselves in the process.

para_meditar.texto: Let nothing be done through strife or vainglory; but in lowliness of mind let each esteem other better than themselves.
But seek ye first the kingdom of God, and his righteousness; and all these things shall be added unto you.
But by the grace of God I am what I am: and his grace which was bestowed upon me was not in vain; but I laboured more abundantly than they all: yet not I, but the grace of God which was with me.

2026-09-06.oracion: Heavenly Father, I thank you for the example of John the Baptist, who understood the importance of decreasing so that Christ might increase. Help me to cultivate a heart of humility, to set aside my own desires and ambitions, and to prioritize your will above all else. Grant me the grace to point others to Jesus, to celebrate His glory, and to rejoice in the advancement of His Kingdom. May I be willing to decrease in influence and recognition, knowing that true joy lies in seeing Christ magnified in the lives of others. Help me to serve you with a selfless spirit, always seeking to honor and glorify your name. Guide me to be a vessel of your love and grace, always pointing to Jesus, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-07.versiculo: 1 John 1:7 KJV: "But if we walk in the light, as he is in the light, we have fellowship one with another, and the blood of Jesus Christ his Son cleanseth us from all sin."
2026-09-07.reflexion: Today's verse, 1 John 1:7, is a profound declaration of both community and cleansing. It paints a beautiful picture of what it means to live a life connected to God and to each other. The key is walking in the light, mirroring God's own nature. This isn't just about avoiding darkness; it's about actively choosing to live in the presence of God, embracing His truth, and reflecting His character. When we walk in the light, we experience fellowship with one another. This isn't merely a social gathering; it's a deep, meaningful connection that transcends superficiality. It's a shared experience of faith, where we support, encourage, and challenge each other to grow closer to Christ. Moreover, the verse highlights the transformative power of Jesus' blood. It cleanses us from all sin, a complete and thorough purification. This cleansing is not a one-time event; it's an ongoing process, made possible by our continued walk in the light. The blood of Jesus is a constant source of grace and forgiveness, available to us as we confess our sins and strive to live in accordance with God's will. This verse calls us to live a life of transparency, honesty, and love, knowing that we are always connected to our brothers and sisters in Christ, and always covered by the blood of Jesus.

para_meditar.texto: Thy word is a lamp unto my feet, and a light unto my path.
Then spake Jesus again unto them, saying, I am the light of the world: he that followeth me shall not walk in darkness, but shall have the light of life.
For ye were sometimes darkness, but now are ye light in the Lord: walk as children of light:

2026-09-07.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the light of Your presence that shines into our lives. Thank you for the gift of fellowship with other believers, and for the cleansing power of Jesus’ blood. Help us to walk in the light, to reflect Your love and truth in all that we do. Grant us the courage to confess our sins and to seek Your forgiveness daily. Guide us to be vessels of Your grace, bringing hope and healing to those around us. Give us a heart for unity, that we may encourage and support one another in our faith journey. May we always remember the sacrifice of Jesus and the freedom that comes through Him. Transform our hearts and minds to be more like Yours, illuminating the world with Your love. We ask all this, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-08.versiculo: 2 Corinthians 1:20 KJV: "For all the promises of God in him are yea, and in him Amen, unto the glory of God by us."
2026-09-08.reflexion: Today's verse, 2 Corinthians 1:20, offers a profound insight into the nature of God's promises. It declares that every single promise of God finds its fulfillment in Jesus Christ. The phrase "yea and Amen" emphasizes the absolute certainty and trustworthiness of these promises. They are not conditional or subject to change; they are unwavering truths rooted in the character of God. This verse is not just an affirmation of God's faithfulness, but also a reminder of our role as witnesses to His glory. Through us, the promises of God are made known and experienced. We are called to live lives that reflect the reality of these promises, allowing them to shape our thoughts, actions, and relationships. When we embrace the promises of God, we find strength in times of weakness, hope in the face of despair, and peace amidst chaos. Let us cling to the steadfastness of God's word, knowing that in Christ, every promise is certain and secure, bringing glory to God through our lives. May we daily meditate on His promises, trusting in their fulfillment and allowing them to guide our steps.

para_meditar.texto: That by two immutable things, in which it was impossible for God to lie, we might have a strong consolation, who have fled for refuge to lay hold upon the hope set before us:
And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to his purpose.
Thy word is true from the beginning: and every one of thy righteous judgments endureth for ever.

2026-09-08.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with hearts full of gratitude for the unwavering promises you have given us in Jesus Christ. We thank you that every promise is 'yea' and 'amen' in Him, and that we can trust in their absolute certainty. Help us to live lives that reflect the reality of your promises, allowing them to shape our thoughts, actions, and relationships. Grant us the faith to cling to your Word, especially in times of trial and uncertainty. Remind us that you are faithful, and that your love endures forever. May we be witnesses of your glory, sharing the hope and peace that come from knowing you. Fill us with your Spirit, that we may walk in obedience to your will and bring honor to your name. We ask all this, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-09.versiculo: Matthew 10:32 KJV: "Whosoever therefore shall confess me before men, him will I confess also before my Father which is in heaven."
2026-09-09.reflexion: Today's verse, Matthew 10:32, offers a profound challenge and promise. Jesus clearly states that confessing Him before others is a prerequisite for being acknowledged by God the Father. This isn't merely a ritualistic declaration, but a genuine acknowledgment of our faith, a living testimony of our relationship with Christ. It requires courage, especially in a world that often ridicules or disregards Christian values. To confess Christ means to live a life that reflects His teachings, embodying love, compassion, and truth. It is about aligning our actions with our beliefs, allowing our faith to permeate every aspect of our existence. The promise is equally significant: if we confess Him, He will confess us before the Father. This is not a transaction, but a reciprocal relationship. Our public acknowledgment of Him is met with His eternal endorsement. This verse reminds us that our faith is not a private matter, but a public declaration. It calls us to be bold in our witness, to live authentically, and to trust in the promise of eternal recognition. It encourages us to embrace the challenge of confessing Christ, knowing that the reward is far greater than any earthly opposition.

para_meditar.texto: That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved.
And that every tongue should confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father.
Whosoever denieth the Son, the same hath not the Father: [but] he that acknowledgeth the Son hath the Father also.

2026-09-09.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the gift of faith and the promise of eternal life. Help me to be bold in my confession of Jesus Christ before others. Grant me the courage to live a life that reflects Your love and truth, even when faced with opposition. Strengthen my resolve to stand firm in my beliefs, and to let my actions be a testament to my faith. Guide me to speak truth and love in every situation, so that I may be a light in the world. May my confession be a constant reminder of Your presence in my life, and a beacon of hope for those around me. Fill my heart with gratitude for the ultimate sacrifice of Jesus, and help me to live worthy of His grace. May I never be ashamed of the Gospel, but rather, always be ready to share the good news with those who need to hear it. I pray all this, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-10.versiculo: John 5:24 KJV: "Verily, verily, I say unto you, He that heareth my word, and believeth on him that sent me, hath everlasting life, and shall not come into condemnation; but is passed from death unto life."
2026-09-10.reflexion: John 5:24 is a cornerstone of Christian faith, a powerful declaration of the assurance we have in Christ. Jesus proclaims that those who hear His word and believe in God, who sent Him, possess eternal life. This is not a promise contingent on perfect performance, but a gift received through faith. The phrase "hath everlasting life" speaks of a present reality, not just a future hope. We already have it! It's a life that transcends the limitations of this earthly existence. Moreover, we "shall not come into condemnation," meaning we are freed from the judgment and penalty of sin. Jesus' sacrifice on the cross has paid the price, and those who believe are covered by His righteousness. The final phrase, "but is passed from death unto life," emphasizes the radical transformation that occurs. We are no longer bound by spiritual death, but are now alive in Christ, enjoying a new relationship with God. This verse invites us to examine our belief. Do we hear His word? Do we believe? If so, we can rest in the assurance of eternal life and the promise of no condemnation.

para_meditar.texto: There is therefore now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.
Verily, verily, I say unto you, He that believeth on me hath everlasting life.
These things have I written unto you that believe on the name of the Son of God; that ye may know that ye have eternal life, and that ye may believe on the name of the Son of God.

2026-09-10.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the incredible promise of John 5:24. Thank you for sending your Son, Jesus, to pay the price for my sins. I acknowledge that I have heard your word and I believe in You. Help me to live each day in the light of your truth, knowing that I have eternal life and am free from condemnation. Grant me a deeper understanding of Your love and grace, and help me to share this good news with others. Help me to walk in the Spirit, and to live a life that honors you. Strengthen my faith, and help me to trust completely in your promises. Guide me and keep me safe, knowing that I am eternally secure in You, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-11.versiculo: Philippians 1:27 KJV: "Only let your conversation be as it becometh the gospel of Christ: that whether I come and see you, or else be absent, I may hear of your affairs, that ye stand fast in one spirit, with one mind striving together for the faith of the gospel;"
2026-09-11.reflexion: Today's verse, Philippians 1:27, calls us to live lives worthy of the Gospel of Christ. This isn't just about what we believe, but how we live. The word 'conversation' here refers to our entire way of life, our conduct, our interactions with others. Paul urges us to ensure our actions reflect the good news we proclaim. He wants to hear that we are standing firm in one spirit, united in mind, and working together for the faith of the gospel. This unity is crucial. It's not just about individual faith; it's about the collective strength of believers working in harmony. We are called to strive together, to contend for the faith, defending and spreading the Gospel. This requires intentionality, a conscious effort to live in a way that honors Christ, even when facing adversity. It means prioritizing unity over division, love over judgment, and the Gospel over personal comfort. Let us examine our lives and ensure our actions align with the glorious message of Jesus Christ, striving together in unity to spread the good news to all.

para_meditar.texto: And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.
Endeavouring to keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace.
Having your conversation honest among the Gentiles: that, whereas they speak against you as evildoers, they may by your good works, which they shall behold, glorify God in the day of visitation.

2026-09-11.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today, seeking your guidance and strength to live lives worthy of the Gospel of Christ. Help us to examine our hearts and actions, ensuring that our conversation, our entire way of life, reflects your love and grace. Grant us the spirit of unity and a shared mind, so that we may stand firm together, striving for the faith of the Gospel. Remove any division or discord from our hearts, and replace it with love, compassion, and understanding. May we be a light in this world, drawing others to you through our words and deeds. Give us the courage to defend and spread the good news, even in the face of adversity. Help us to prioritize your will above our own desires, and may we always seek to glorify your name in all that we do. We ask this, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-12.versiculo: Galatians 1:4 KJV: "Who gave himself for our sins, that he might deliver us from this present evil world, according to the will of God and our Father:"
2026-09-12.reflexion: Today's verse, Galatians 1:4, encapsulates the very heart of the Gospel: the self-sacrificing love of Jesus Christ. Paul emphasizes that Jesus 'gave himself for our sins'. This wasn't a casual act; it was a deliberate, costly act of love, a voluntary offering of his perfect life to atone for our transgressions. He did this, not just to forgive our sins, but to deliver us from 'this present evil world.' This world, with its temptations, its darkness, and its hold on our hearts, is a place from which we need to be rescued. Jesus' sacrifice provides that rescue. It is a liberation from the dominion of sin and death. The verse concludes by affirming that this act of redemption is 'according to the will of God and our Father.' This highlights the divine plan, the unwavering purpose of God to restore humanity to himself. It's a reminder that our salvation is not a mere accident or a human invention, but the fulfillment of God's eternal plan. To truly grasp this verse is to understand the depth of God's love and the transformative power of the Gospel. It's a call to live a life of gratitude and to actively pursue the freedom that Christ has won for us.

para_meditar.texto: For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.
But God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.
Who his own self bare our sins in his own body on the tree, that we, being dead to sins, should live unto righteousness: by whose stripes ye were healed.

2026-09-12.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you with grateful hearts, acknowledging the profound sacrifice of your Son, Jesus Christ. We thank you for giving Himself for our sins, delivering us from the bondage of this evil world. Help us to understand more deeply the magnitude of your love, the cost of our redemption. Grant us the grace to live lives that reflect the freedom we have in Christ. May we resist the temptations of this world and instead seek to live according to your will. Strengthen our faith, increase our hope, and fill us with your peace. Help us to share the good news of salvation with those who are still lost, that they too may experience the joy of your forgiveness. We dedicate ourselves to You, striving to live as a reflection of Your love and grace, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-13.versiculo: Matthew 21:42 KJV: "Jesus saith unto them, Did ye never read in the scriptures, The stone which the builders rejected, the same is become the head of the corner: this is the Lord's doing, and it is marvellous in our eyes?"
2026-09-13.reflexion: Today's verse, Matthew 21:42, speaks of the cornerstone rejected by the builders, which then becomes the head of the corner. This powerful imagery is a direct reference to Jesus Christ. The builders, representing those in authority, the religious leaders of the time, rejected Him. They failed to recognize His true identity as the Messiah, the foundation upon which all else is built. However, God, in His divine wisdom, chose Jesus, the rejected stone, to be the cornerstone, the most vital part of the structure. This verse reminds us that God often chooses the unexpected, the seemingly insignificant, to accomplish His purposes. Those who reject Christ are ultimately rejecting the very foundation of salvation and eternal life. We are called to examine our own hearts and ensure that we are building our lives upon the solid rock of Jesus Christ. Let us not be like the builders who stumbled at the cornerstone, but rather embrace Him as the most precious and important element in our lives. This verse should inspire us to see God's hand at work, even in the midst of rejection and adversity, and to trust in His sovereignty and wisdom.

para_meditar.texto: The stone which the builders refused is become the head stone of the corner.
Therefore thus saith the Lord GOD, Behold, I lay in Zion for a foundation a stone, a tried stone, a precious corner stone, a sure foundation: he that believeth shall not make haste.
Wherefore also it is contained in the scripture, Behold, I lay in Sion a chief corner stone, elect, precious: and he that believeth on him shall not be confounded.

2026-09-13.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the cornerstone, Jesus Christ, upon whom our lives are built. We acknowledge that sometimes we, like the builders of old, can be tempted to reject what is most important. Forgive us when we fail to recognize Your presence and Your plans in our lives. Help us to see Your hand at work, even in the midst of difficult circumstances. Grant us the wisdom to build our lives on the solid foundation of faith in Jesus, so that we may stand firm and be a beacon of hope to others. Guide us to embrace Christ as our Lord and Savior, the head of the corner, and to live in accordance with Your will. Strengthen our faith, deepen our trust, and fill us with Your peace, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-14.versiculo: Mark 7:23 KJV: "All these evil things come from within, and defile the man."
2026-09-14.reflexion: Today's verse, Mark 7:23, offers a stark reminder of the source of our spiritual defilement. Jesus declares that evil doesn't originate from external forces, but from within the human heart. This is a profound truth that challenges us to look inwards, to examine the thoughts, intentions, and desires that govern our lives. The 'evil things' mentioned encompass a wide range of sins, from the obvious to the subtle: malice, pride, deceit, and envy, among others. These are not just isolated actions; they are symptoms of a deeper problem, a corrupted nature that inclines us towards sin. The defilement, the moral pollution, originates in the heart and then manifests in our words and deeds. This understanding is critical because it highlights the need for internal transformation. Merely trying to control external behaviors without addressing the internal source of sin is a futile endeavor. We need a new heart, a heart cleansed and renewed by the grace of God through faith in Jesus Christ. This requires a constant awareness of our inner state, a willingness to confess our sins, and a dependence on the Holy Spirit to guide and empower us to overcome the temptations that arise from within.

para_meditar.texto: Create in me a clean heart, O God; and renew a right spirit within me.
Keep thy heart with all diligence; for out of it are the issues of life.
For I delight in the law of God after the inward man: But I see another law in my members, warring against the law of my mind, and bringing me into captivity to the law of sin which is in my members.

2026-09-14.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today acknowledging the truth of Mark 7:23. We recognize that the source of our sin lies within our own hearts. We confess our tendency towards evil thoughts and desires, and we ask for your forgiveness. Search our hearts, O God, and reveal any areas of darkness that need your light. Help us to cultivate a heart that is pure and pleasing to you. Give us the strength to resist the temptations that arise from within, and fill us with your Holy Spirit, that we may walk in righteousness and truth. Guide us to think, speak, and act in ways that honor you. Help us to guard our hearts and to seek your guidance in all things. Thank you for your love, your grace, and your mercy, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-15.versiculo: Colossians 1:27 KJV: "To whom God would make known what is the riches of the glory of this mystery among the Gentiles; which is Christ in you, the hope of glory:"
2026-09-15.reflexion: Today's verse, Colossians 1:27, unveils a profound truth: Christ in you, the hope of glory. This mystery, hidden for ages, is now revealed—God's plan to dwell within believers, both Jew and Gentile. The 'riches of the glory' are not just external blessings, but the indwelling presence of Jesus, the very essence of hope. It's not a fleeting sentiment, but a concrete expectation of future glory, a promise of eternal life and intimate fellowship with God. This verse speaks of a transformation that begins now. Christ's presence is not merely a belief, but a reality that empowers us to live victoriously, to overcome challenges, and to love others with a love that surpasses understanding. The hope of glory fuels our perseverance, our faith, and our witness to the world. We are not alone in this journey; the very Son of God resides within us, offering strength, guidance, and the assurance of a glorious future. This is the core of our faith, a truth that should fill us with joy, gratitude, and a renewed commitment to live a life worthy of the calling we have received.

para_meditar.texto: But if the Spirit of him that raised up Jesus from the dead dwell in you, he that raised up Christ from the dead shall also quicken your mortal bodies by his Spirit that dwelleth in you.

I am crucified with Christ: nevertheless I live; yet not I, but Christ liveth in me: and the life which I now live in the flesh I live by the faith of the Son of God, who loved me, and gave himself for me.
Beloved, now are we the sons of God, and it doth not yet appear what we shall be: but we know that, when he shall appear, we shall be like him; for we shall see him as he is.

2026-09-15.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the incredible gift of Christ in me, the hope of glory. Thank you for revealing this mystery, that You would choose to dwell within Your children. Help me to fully grasp the magnitude of this truth and to live each day in the awareness of Your presence. Grant me strength to overcome the temptations and challenges that I face, knowing that Your Spirit within me is greater than anything that could come against me. Fill me with Your love, Your joy, and Your peace, that I may reflect Your glory to those around me. May my life be a testament to the hope that I have in You, and may I be a faithful witness to Your love and grace. Give me a heart that yearns for a deeper relationship with You, and a life that is pleasing in Your sight. I pray for the strength to live a life of purpose, reflecting Christ in all that I do, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-16.versiculo: 1 Peter 2:21 KJV: "For even hereunto were ye called: because Christ also suffered for us, leaving us an example, that ye should follow his steps:"
2026-09-16.reflexion: Today's passage from 1 Peter 2:21 offers a profound challenge and encouragement. It reminds us that we were called to a specific purpose: to follow in the footsteps of Christ. This verse isn't just a suggestion; it's a declaration of our calling. Christ suffered for us, enduring unimaginable pain and humiliation, not just to atone for our sins, but also to leave us an example. He demonstrated how to live a life of unwavering faith, humility, and obedience, even amidst suffering. The 'steps' we are to follow are those of Christ: His love, His compassion, His forgiveness, and His unwavering commitment to the will of the Father.  This means embracing a life of service, putting others before ourselves, and bearing our own crosses with grace. It calls us to resist the temptation of worldly desires and to choose instead the path of righteousness, even when it's difficult. It's a reminder that our trials and tribulations, when endured with faith, can be a powerful testimony to God's grace and a means of drawing closer to Him.  Let us strive to emulate Christ's life, allowing His example to guide our thoughts, words, and actions, and remembering that we are not alone in our journey, for He walks with us every step of the way.

para_meditar.texto: Let this mind be in you, which was also in Christ Jesus:
Looking unto Jesus the author and finisher of our faith; who for the joy that was set before him endured the cross, despising the shame, and is set down at the right hand of the throne of God.
For I have given you an example, that ye should do as I have done to you.

2026-09-16.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank You for the ultimate example of love and sacrifice in Your Son, Jesus Christ. We are grateful for the call to follow in His footsteps, to learn from His life, and to emulate His character. Help us, Lord, to be mindful of His teachings and to live in accordance with His will. Grant us the strength to bear our crosses with grace and the courage to stand for righteousness, even in the face of adversity. Open our hearts to embrace humility, compassion, and service. Guide us to reflect Christ in all that we do, so that others may see You in us and be drawn to You. We pray for the Holy Spirit to empower us to walk in truth and to be a light in this world. We ask for your guidance and strength to follow your Son's example, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-17.versiculo: Mark 9:35 KJV: "And he sat down, and called the twelve, and saith unto them, If any man desire to be first, the same shall be last of all, and servant of all."
2026-09-17.reflexion: Today's verse from Mark 9:35 offers a profound challenge to our understanding of greatness. Jesus, observing his disciples' squabble over who was the greatest, provides a counter-cultural teaching. He doesn't offer them a path to power through dominance or prestige. Instead, he inverts the world's values, declaring that the path to true greatness lies in servanthood. This passage challenges us to examine our own ambitions and desires. Do we strive for recognition, position, and control, or do we seek opportunities to serve, to put others' needs before our own? The disciples, like us, often struggled with this. They were human, prone to the same temptations of pride and self-importance. Jesus' response is a call to humility, a reminder that true leadership is found in selfless service. This verse is not just a command, but a promise. By embracing servanthood, we position ourselves to be truly great in the eyes of God. It's a reminder that the blessings of God are often found in the most unexpected places, in the quiet acts of kindness, and the humble willingness to serve others.

para_meditar.texto: Let nothing be done through strife or vainglory; but in lowliness of mind let each esteem other better than themselves.
Even as the Son of man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give his life a ransom for many.
If I then, your Lord and Master, have washed your feet; ye also ought to wash one another's feet.

2026-09-17.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You humbled by the words of Jesus. Forgive us when we seek our own glory and recognition. Open our hearts to see the needs of others and to embrace the spirit of servanthood. Help us to lay down our pride and to serve with a willing and loving heart, just as Jesus served us. Grant us the strength to be the last and the servant of all, knowing that in Your Kingdom, this is the path to true greatness. Give us the grace to emulate Christ's example in all that we do, and to find joy in serving others. Guide us to be humble and to put the needs of others before our own. We thank you for Your love, mercy, and guidance. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-18.versiculo: Hebrews 2:1 KJV: "Therefore we ought to give the more earnest heed to the things which we have heard, lest at any time we should let them slip."
2026-09-18.reflexion:
Today’s verse from Hebrews 2:1 calls us to give ‘the more earnest heed’ to the truths we have received. It’s a profound call to vigilance, urging us to actively engage with the message of the Gospel lest we allow it to drift away. The writer of Hebrews is speaking to a community that had already heard the good news, the message of salvation through Jesus Christ. The danger wasn't ignorance of the message, but rather a potential for spiritual apathy, a tendency to become distracted by the world and to neglect the eternal truths they had embraced. 

'Earnest heed' implies a focused attention, a deliberate effort to listen, understand, and apply the teachings of Christ. It requires us to be intentional in our study of Scripture, in our prayer life, and in our fellowship with other believers. It means being present in the moment, actively listening to the Holy Spirit, and allowing His guidance to shape our thoughts and actions. The warning against letting these things 'slip' is a serious one. Like a boat drifting from its moorings, neglecting the Word can lead us away from the safe harbor of faith and into the stormy seas of doubt and despair. Let us therefore, hold fast to the word and diligently apply ourselves to the truth of the Gospel.

para_meditar.texto: Keep thy heart with all diligence; for out of it are the issues of life.
But seek ye first the kingdom of God, and his righteousness; and all these things shall be added unto you.
And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.

2026-09-18.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with hearts open and ready to receive your Word. We acknowledge the importance of paying close attention to the message of the Gospel, and we pray for the strength to remain vigilant against the distractions of the world. Help us to cultivate a deeper understanding of Your truth and to allow it to shape our lives. Grant us the diligence to study Your Word, to pray without ceasing, and to fellowship with other believers. Help us to hold fast to the truth we have heard, guarding it carefully in our hearts. Give us the wisdom to discern Your will and the courage to follow Your path. May we never let the precious truths of the Gospel slip away. We ask all these things in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-19.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 14:33 KJV: "For God is not the author of confusion, but of peace, as in all churches of the saints."
2026-09-19.reflexion:
Today's verse, 1 Corinthians 14:33, provides a powerful insight into the nature of God. It declares that God is not the author of confusion, but of peace. This simple statement holds profound implications for our lives and the way we approach our faith. Confusion often arises from a lack of understanding, a multiplicity of voices, or a chaotic environment. God, however, is the embodiment of order, clarity, and tranquility. He desires peace, not only in our hearts but also in the church and in all aspects of our lives. 

This verse reminds us that when we experience confusion, it is not from God. It is a call to seek His peace, to find clarity in His Word, and to align ourselves with His purposes. It encourages us to seek unity and harmony, both individually and within the body of Christ. The phrase 'as in all churches of the saints' further emphasizes that this principle is universal. Peace and order should be the hallmarks of every gathering of believers, reflecting the very character of God. Therefore, let us strive to cultivate an environment of peace, understanding, and unity in all our endeavors, knowing that God is the source of it all.

para_meditar.texto: And the peace of God, which passeth all understanding, shall keep your hearts and minds through Christ Jesus.
Peace I leave with you, my peace I give unto you: not as the world giveth, give I unto you. Let not your heart be troubled, neither let it be afraid.
Let us therefore follow after the things which make for peace, and things wherewith one may edify another.

2026-09-19.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for revealing Your nature as the God of peace. Thank you that You are not the author of confusion, but of clarity, order, and tranquility. Help me to recognize when confusion seeks to cloud my mind and heart. Grant me discernment to discern Your voice amidst the chaos. Fill me with Your peace, which surpasses all understanding, and guide me in ways that bring harmony and unity to my relationships and actions. Help me to be a vessel of Your peace in the world, reflecting Your love and grace to all those I encounter. Help me to build and live my life in peace, in every area of my life, according to Your will. I pray for peace in my heart, in my home, and in my community, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-20.versiculo: Colossians 2:10 KJV: "And ye are complete in him, which is the head of all principality and power."
2026-09-20.reflexion: Today's verse, Colossians 2:10, is a powerful declaration of our completeness in Christ. It proclaims that we, as believers, are made whole in Him. This doesn't mean we are perfect in our earthly journey, but rather, in Christ, we lack nothing. We are fully equipped with all we need for salvation, life, and godliness. The verse emphasizes that Christ is the head of all authority and power. This is a crucial aspect of understanding our completeness in Him. All earthly principalities and powers are subject to Christ. Therefore, when we are in Christ, we are connected to the ultimate source of authority and strength. This truth should reshape our perspective on life. When faced with challenges, doubts, or fears, we can find refuge and strength in knowing we are complete in Him. We have access to His wisdom, grace, and power. Our identity is found in Christ, not in our accomplishments, failures, or circumstances. This realization brings freedom from the pressures of the world and allows us to live with confidence and joy, knowing we are already complete in Him. Embrace this truth today, and let it transform your thoughts and actions.

para_meditar.texto: And hath put all things under his feet, and gave him to be the head over all things to the church, Which is his body, the fulness of him that filleth all in all.
I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me.
And of his fulness have all we received, and grace for grace.

2026-09-20.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the incredible truth of Colossians 2:10. Thank you for making us complete in Christ. We acknowledge that He is the head of all principality and power, and that in Him, we lack nothing. Help us to truly grasp this reality, to live each day with the confidence and peace that comes from knowing we are complete in Him. Grant us the strength to overcome our weaknesses and the wisdom to navigate the challenges of this world. Open our eyes to see Your grace and provision in every situation. Guide us to live lives that reflect our completeness in Christ, sharing His love and truth with others. May we always remember that our identity is found in You. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, empowering us to live a life worthy of the calling we have received. We surrender our lives to You, trusting in Your unwavering love and guidance. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-21.versiculo: Revelation 22:12-13 KJV: "And, behold, I come quickly; and my reward is with me, to give every man according as his work shall be. I am Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the end, the first and the last."
2026-09-21.reflexion: These verses from Revelation offer a powerful message of anticipation and accountability. The Lord declares His imminent return, emphasizing the reality of judgment and reward. "Behold, I come quickly; and my reward is with me." This statement should stir both excitement and introspection within us. It reminds us that our actions in this life have eternal consequences. The reward is not merely a future promise, but something the Lord brings with Him, signifying its certainty and nearness. We are called to live in light of this truth, striving to do good works that are pleasing to God. The second part of the verse, "I am Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the end, the first and the last," highlights the eternal nature of Christ. He is the source and the culmination of all things. This declaration underscores His authority and sovereignty. It assures us that the ultimate outcome of history, and of our individual lives, is in His capable hands. Knowing this, we can trust in His plan, even when the present seems uncertain. Let us therefore live each day with a heart ready to meet the Lord, seeking to please Him in all that we do, and trusting in His eternal promise.

para_meditar.texto: For the Son of man shall come in the glory of his Father with his angels; and then he shall reward every man according to his works.

Every man's work shall be made manifest: for the day shall declare it, because it shall be revealed by fire; and the fire shall try every man's work of what sort it is. If any man's work abide which he hath built thereupon, he shall receive a reward. If any man's work shall be burned, he shall suffer loss: but he himself shall be saved; yet so as by fire.

For our conversation is in heaven; from whence also we look for the Saviour, the Lord Jesus Christ: Who shall change our vile body, that it may be fashioned like unto his glorious body, according to the working whereby he is able even to subdue all things unto himself.

2026-09-21.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the promise of your swift return and the assurance of your eternal presence. Help us to live each day with a sense of urgency, striving to do good works that bring glory to your name. Grant us the wisdom to discern your will and the strength to follow it faithfully. Remind us constantly that our actions have eternal consequences and that we will be judged according to your righteousness. May we look forward to your coming with joyful anticipation, knowing that our reward is with you. Give us a heart filled with faith, hope, and love, so that we may be ready to meet you. Guide us to be more like you in all that we do, so that when you return, we will be found faithful. We pray for your grace and mercy, and for the strength to endure until the end, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-22.versiculo: Luke 23:34 KJV: "Then said Jesus, Father, forgive them; for they know not what they do. And they parted his raiment, and cast lots."
2026-09-22.reflexion: The words of Jesus from the cross, "Father, forgive them; for they know not what they do," are a profound testament to the boundless nature of God's love and mercy. In the midst of excruciating physical and emotional suffering, Jesus' primary concern was not for Himself, but for the forgiveness of those who were crucifying Him. This act of forgiveness transcends human understanding; it is a direct reflection of the divine character. Jesus recognized the ignorance of those who condemned Him, understanding that their actions stemmed from a lack of knowledge and understanding. This does not excuse their actions, but rather highlights the depth of Jesus' compassion and His desire for their salvation. We, too, are often guilty of actions driven by ignorance, whether intentional or unintentional. Jesus' prayer serves as a powerful reminder to examine our own hearts and seek forgiveness for our transgressions, as well as to extend forgiveness to those who have wronged us. It challenges us to mirror the grace of Christ in our daily lives, choosing love and compassion over resentment and bitterness. This verse is a cornerstone of Christian faith, urging us to embrace forgiveness as a central tenet of our walk with God.

para_meditar.texto: But I say unto you, Love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them which despitefully use you, and persecute you;
And be ye kind one to another, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, even as God for Christ's sake hath forgiven you.
Forbearing one another, and forgiving one another, if any man have a quarrel against any: even as Christ forgave you, so also do ye.

2026-09-22.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You today humbled and awestruck by the example of Jesus Christ. We thank You for His unwavering love and forgiveness, demonstrated so powerfully on the cross. Lord, we pray for the strength to emulate His compassion and to forgive those who have wronged us. Help us to recognize our own shortcomings and to seek Your forgiveness for our ignorance and our sins. Grant us the grace to see others through Your eyes, understanding their struggles and extending mercy as You have shown us mercy. Fill our hearts with Your love, that we may be instruments of reconciliation and peace in a world desperately in need of Your grace. Guide us to walk in forgiveness, just as Christ walked in forgiveness, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-23.versiculo: 1 Peter 3:14 KJV: "But and if ye suffer for righteousness' sake, happy are ye: and be not afraid of their terror, neither be troubled;"
2026-09-23.reflexion: Today's verse offers a profound comfort and challenge to believers facing adversity. Peter, writing to persecuted Christians, reminds us that suffering for righteousness is not a sign of failure, but a testament to our faith. It is a pathway to happiness, not in a worldly sense, but in the deep, abiding joy that comes from knowing we are pleasing God. The key lies in the exhortation: "be not afraid of their terror, neither be troubled." This is not a call to stoicism, but an invitation to trust in God's sovereignty. Fear and trouble are natural reactions to suffering, but Peter encourages us to rise above these emotions. To do so, we must root ourselves in the understanding that God is with us, that He sees our pain, and that He will ultimately vindicate us. This verse calls us to examine our hearts, to ensure our suffering is truly for righteousness' sake – for the sake of living a life that honors God. Are we willing to endure hardship for the sake of our faith? Are we willing to stand firm in the face of opposition? This verse reminds us that even in the midst of suffering, we can find joy and peace in Christ, knowing that we are part of a larger story, a story of redemption and eternal glory.

para_meditar.texto: For I reckon that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which shall be revealed in us.
Blessed are they which are persecuted for righteousness' sake: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
For unto you it is given in the behalf of Christ, not only to believe on him, but also to suffer for his sake;

2026-09-23.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the comfort and encouragement found in Your Word. Thank You for reminding us that suffering for righteousness is a blessing, a sign of our connection to You. Help us, Lord, to not be afraid of the trials we face, but to trust in Your unwavering presence and love. Give us the strength to stand firm in our faith, even when the world seeks to intimidate us. Grant us the wisdom to discern the true source of our suffering, ensuring it is for Your glory and not for selfish gain. Fill us with Your peace that surpasses all understanding, so that we may remain steadfast, joyful, and a shining light for You. Help us to remember that You are in control and that You will never leave us nor forsake us. We commit our lives to You, trusting in Your perfect plan, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-24.versiculo: Matthew 18:3 KJV: "And said, Verily I say unto you, Except ye be converted, and become as little children, ye shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven."
2026-09-24.reflexion: Today's verse, Matthew 18:3, presents a profound and challenging truth: the necessity of humility and childlike faith for entering the Kingdom of Heaven. Jesus emphasizes that we must undergo a transformation, a 'conversion,' and adopt the simplicity and trust of a little child. In the context of this chapter, Jesus is addressing the disciples' concerns about who is the greatest in the Kingdom. His response reveals that greatness is not found in worldly ambition or status, but in a humble, teachable spirit. Children, in their innocence and dependence, readily embrace trust and are open to receiving. They are not burdened by pride or self-importance. To 'become as little children' means to shed the layers of cynicism, self-reliance, and preconceived notions that often cloud our relationship with God. It means embracing a posture of vulnerability, recognizing our dependence on Him, and accepting His guidance with a simple, trusting heart. This is not about literal childishness, but about cultivating a spirit of humility, teachability, and unwavering faith. It's a call to return to the core of our relationship with God, where the focus is on love, trust, and a complete reliance on His grace. Only through this transformation can we truly experience the blessings and joys of the Kingdom.

para_meditar.texto: Surely I have behaved and quieted myself, as a child that is weaned of his mother: my soul is even as a weaned child.
Verily I say unto you, Whosoever shall not receive the kingdom of God as a little child, he shall not enter therein.
Trust in the Lord with all thine heart; and lean not unto thine own understanding. In all thy ways acknowledge him, and he shall direct thy paths.

2026-09-24.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today humbled and seeking your guidance. I recognize that I often struggle with pride and self-reliance, and I ask for your forgiveness. Help me to be transformed, to be converted, and to become like a little child in my faith. Grant me a humble and teachable spirit, that I may readily embrace your love and guidance. Remove the barriers of cynicism and self-importance that stand between me and you. Help me to trust in you completely, leaning not on my own understanding, but acknowledging you in all my ways. Give me the strength to surrender my will to yours, and to live a life of simple, trusting faith. Thank you for your unwavering love and grace. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-25.versiculo: Colossians 3:10 KJV: "And have put on the new man, which is renewed in knowledge after the image of him that created him:"
2026-09-25.reflexion: Today's verse in Colossians 3:10 speaks of the incredible transformation available to believers in Christ. It tells us that we have 'put on the new man,' a spiritual rebirth, a complete renewal. This new man is not just a different version of our former selves; it's a new creation, fashioned in the image of God. This renewal happens in knowledge, meaning that as we grow in our understanding of God's Word and His will, we are further transformed. The 'image of him that created him' points directly to Christ, the perfect reflection of God. This verse encourages us to continually seek to know God more fully, to read His Word, to pray, and to seek His guidance in all things. As we do, we are progressively conformed to the image of Christ, becoming more like Him in our thoughts, actions, and attitudes. This is a lifelong journey of learning, growing, and being renewed by the Holy Spirit. It's a call to embrace our new identity in Christ, shedding the old self and embracing the new man who is being continually renewed in knowledge.

para_meditar.texto: And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.
Therefore if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature: old things are passed away; behold, all things are become new.
And be renewed in the spirit of your mind;

2026-09-25.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the gift of the new man in Christ. Thank you for the promise of renewal, the opportunity to shed the old self and embrace the life you have for us. Help us to continually seek knowledge of you, to study your Word, and to grow in understanding. Grant us the strength to resist temptation and to walk in the light of your truth. Fill us with your Holy Spirit and guide us on our journey of transformation. Help us to become more like Christ in all that we do, think, and say. May our lives be a reflection of your glory. Thank you for the grace and mercy you have shown us. We offer this prayer in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-26.versiculo: 1 Timothy 3:9 KJV: "Holding the mystery of the faith in a pure conscience."
2026-09-26.reflexion: Today's verse, 1 Timothy 3:9, speaks to the importance of maintaining a pure conscience while holding fast to the mysteries of the faith. The 'mystery of the faith' refers to the core truths of Christianity, often those things that are revealed to us by God, and which are not fully understood by human intellect. These are the foundational beliefs of the Gospel - the divinity of Christ, the Trinity, the atoning sacrifice, and the resurrection. To hold these mysteries with a pure conscience means to accept and live out these truths with integrity and honesty. A pure conscience is one that is free from guilt and moral compromise. It is the result of a life lived in obedience to God's word and the leading of the Holy Spirit. It is essential for leaders within the church, but it is a standard that applies to all believers. When our conscience is clear, we have a sense of peace and assurance in our relationship with God. We are able to approach Him with confidence, knowing that we are striving to live a life pleasing to Him. This purity of heart allows us to be effective witnesses for Christ, as our actions and words are in harmony with our beliefs. It also protects us from being easily swayed by false teachings or temptations to compromise our faith. Therefore, let us cultivate a pure conscience through prayer, scripture reading, and obedience, enabling us to faithfully hold fast to the mysteries of our faith.

para_meditar.texto: Keep thy heart with all diligence; for out of it are the issues of life.
Let us draw near with a true heart in full assurance of faith, having our hearts sprinkled from an evil conscience, and our bodies washed with pure water.
The like figure whereunto even baptism doth also now save us (not the putting away of the filth of the flesh, but the answer of a good conscience toward God,) by the resurrection of Jesus Christ:

2026-09-26.oracion: Heavenly Father, I thank you for the gift of faith and for revealing the mysteries of your kingdom to me. I pray that you would help me to hold fast to these truths with a pure conscience. Grant me the grace to examine my heart and to confess any sin that hinders my relationship with you. Help me to be honest and upright in all my dealings, both with you and with others. Fill me with the Holy Spirit, so that I may be guided by your truth and live a life that is pleasing to you. Give me discernment to recognize and reject false teachings, and strengthen me to stand firm in my faith. I pray for a clean heart and a renewed spirit, that I may serve you with integrity and joy. Help me to walk in the light of your word and to be a faithful witness to your love and grace. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-27.versiculo: James 2:26 KJV: "For as the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without works is dead also."
2026-09-27.reflexion: Today's verse, James 2:26, cuts to the heart of authentic Christian living. It paints a vivid picture: just as a body without breath is lifeless, so too is faith without action. We are not saved by works, but genuine faith will inevitably manifest itself in works. A faith that remains dormant, a faith that does not express itself in love, compassion, and obedience, is a dead faith. This verse challenges us to examine our own lives. Are we merely professing belief, or are we actively demonstrating our faith through our actions? Do our lives reflect the transformative power of the Gospel? The call is to move beyond intellectual assent to a living, breathing faith. It's about more than just saying the right words; it's about living a life that reflects the love and teachings of Jesus Christ. It's about feeding the hungry, clothing the naked, visiting the sick, and caring for the marginalized. It is a call to put our faith into action, demonstrating the reality of our relationship with God through acts of love and service, reflecting the very spirit of Christ.

para_meditar.texto: Not every one that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven; but he that doeth the will of my Father which is in heaven.
For in Jesus Christ neither circumcision availeth any thing, nor uncircumcision; but faith which worketh by love.
My little children, let us not love in word, neither in tongue; but in deed and in truth.

2026-09-27.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the gift of faith and for the clarity of your Word. Help us to understand the true nature of faith, that it is not merely a belief but a living, active force in our lives. Guide us to demonstrate our faith through our works, reflecting Your love and compassion in all that we do. Grant us the wisdom to discern the needs of others and the strength to act upon them. May our lives be a testament to Your grace and a beacon of hope to those around us. Help us to walk in obedience, putting our faith into action, and living a life that pleases you. We ask all these things in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-28.versiculo: 2 Corinthians 11:14 KJV: "And no marvel; for Satan himself is transformed into an angel of light."
2026-09-28.reflexion: The Apostle Paul, in 2 Corinthians 11:14, warns us of a deceptive reality: Satan disguises himself. This isn't a literal transformation into a being with wings and a halo, but a subtler, more insidious manipulation. He masquerades as something good, something appealing, something that might even seem to lead to light. This verse serves as a stark reminder that appearances can be deceiving. Satan's primary weapon is deceit, and he uses it to lead us astray. He twists truth, sows doubt, and presents sin in attractive packages. We must not be naive. We must not assume that everything that glitters is gold. The 'angels of light' that Satan transforms into are not necessarily immediately recognizable as evil. They may appear as charismatic leaders, compelling ideologies, or enticing philosophies. The key is discernment. We must constantly examine what we are exposed to, comparing it to the unwavering truth of God's Word. We must be vigilant, prayerful, and rooted in the knowledge of Christ to see through the illusions and resist the temptations that Satan presents. Only by recognizing the potential for deception can we truly stand firm in our faith and protect ourselves from his schemes.

para_meditar.texto: Be sober, be vigilant; because your adversary the devil, as a roaring lion, walketh about, seeking whom he may devour.
Put on the whole armour of God, that ye may be able to stand against the wiles of the devil.

Ye are of your father the devil, and the lusts of your father ye will do. He was a murderer from the beginning, and abode not in the truth, because there is no truth in him. When he speaketh a lie, he speaketh of his own: for he is a liar, and the father of it.

2026-09-28.oracion: Lord, we recognize the reality of spiritual warfare and the cunning of the enemy. We confess our vulnerability to deception and ask for your protection. Grant us discernment to see through the masks of evil and to recognize the schemes of Satan. Help us to be vigilant in our thoughts, words, and actions, always comparing them to the truth of Your Word. Give us the strength to resist temptation and to stand firm in our faith. Clothe us with the armor of God, and guide us with Your Holy Spirit. Help us to be aware of the subtle ways Satan tries to deceive us, and grant us wisdom to navigate the world with Your truth as our guide. Thank you for the promise of victory over the enemy. We commit ourselves to You, seeking to live a life that honors You. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-29.versiculo: Matthew 13:23 KJV: "But he that received seed into the good ground is he that heareth the word, and understandeth it; which also beareth fruit, and bringeth forth, some an hundredfold, some sixtyfold, some thirtyfold."
2026-09-29.reflexion: Today’s verse, Matthew 13:23, offers a powerful metaphor for the Christian life. The parable of the sower illustrates how the Word of God, the seed, falls upon different types of ground, representing different hearts. In this verse, we focus on the good ground, the heart that not only hears the Word but also understands it. This understanding is not merely intellectual; it is a receptive, spiritual comprehension that allows the seed to take root and grow. The result is fruitfulness—a life transformed by the Word, producing a harvest that varies in abundance (a hundredfold, sixtyfold, or thirtyfold). This variation highlights that while all believers are called to bear fruit, the degree of fruitfulness can differ. What matters most is the receptivity of our hearts. Are we cultivating good ground? Are we making an effort to understand the Word, meditate on it, and allow it to shape our thoughts, actions, and desires? This involves consistent study, prayer, and a willingness to apply biblical principles to our daily lives. It requires a heart that is open, humble, and eager to learn. The fruit we bear is evidence of our transformed lives and the impact of the gospel. Let us strive to be those who hear, understand, and bear abundant fruit for the glory of God.

para_meditar.texto: Keep thy heart with all diligence; for out of it are the issues of life.
And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.
But be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving your own selves.

2026-09-29.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the gift of your Word, the seed that brings life. I pray that you will soften my heart, remove the weeds of doubt and distraction, and cultivate good soil within me. Help me to not only hear your Word but to understand it deeply, allowing it to penetrate my thoughts, actions, and desires. Grant me the wisdom to apply your teachings to my daily life, and to bear abundant fruit for your glory. May I be a vessel of your love and grace, reflecting your character in all that I do. Guide me to be a diligent student of your Word, always seeking to know you more intimately. Strengthen my faith and help me to live a life that is pleasing to you. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-09-30.versiculo: Hebrews 12:11 KJV: "Now no chastening for the present seemeth to be joyous, but grievous: nevertheless afterward it yieldeth the peaceable fruit of righteousness unto them which are exercised thereby."
2026-09-30.reflexion: Hebrews 12:11 offers profound insight into the nature of discipline in the Christian life. The verse acknowledges the immediate pain and discomfort associated with correction, highlighting that it often feels anything but joyful in the moment. This is a crucial truth; our fleshly nature resists pain and discomfort. However, the promise of 'the peaceable fruit of righteousness' offers a perspective shift. This fruit, representing the character of Christ, is a harvest of righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Ghost. The key lies in 'them which are exercised thereby'. This signifies those who are trained and disciplined by the chastening, who submit to the refining fire. It's not enough to endure the hardship; we must learn from it, allowing it to shape us. This requires humility, repentance, and a willingness to change. The suffering itself isn't the goal; it's the means. God uses trials to purify our faith, to prune away the dead branches of sin, and to cultivate the fruit of the Spirit. The ultimate reward is a closer walk with God and a character that reflects His glory. This verse encourages us to trust God's loving hand, even when it feels painful, knowing that He is shaping us for His good purposes.

para_meditar.texto: For whom the LORD loveth he correcteth; even as a father the son in whom he delighteth.

And not only so, but we glory in tribulations also: knowing that tribulation worketh patience; And patience, experience; and experience, hope: And hope maketh not ashamed; because the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Ghost which is given unto us.

My brethren, count it all joy when ye fall into divers temptations; Knowing this, that the trying of your faith worketh patience. But let patience have her perfect work, that ye may be perfect and entire, wanting nothing.

2026-09-30.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the gift of Your love and the discipline that comes with it. I acknowledge that sometimes, the trials and corrections feel difficult and grievous. Help me to remember the promise of the peaceable fruit of righteousness, and to see beyond the immediate pain. Grant me the humility to learn from these experiences, to submit to Your refining work, and to grow closer to You. Give me the strength to endure and to trust in Your perfect plan for my life. May I be exercised by Your chastening, and may I bear the fruit of the Spirit in all that I do. Fill me with Your peace, and guide me on the path of righteousness. I pray for wisdom and discernment to understand Your will and to walk in obedience. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-10-01.versiculo: James 1:2-4 KJV: "My brethren, count it all joy when ye fall into divers temptations; Knowing this, that the trying of your faith worketh patience. But let patience have her perfect work, that ye may be perfect and entire, wanting nothing."
2026-10-01.reflexion: Today’s passage from James encourages us to embrace trials with joy, recognizing their transformative power. It’s a counter-intuitive call, urging us to view difficulties not as obstacles, but as opportunities for growth. James emphasizes that these 'divers temptations' are not punishments, but rather tools used by God to refine our faith. The testing of our faith produces patience, a virtue essential for spiritual maturity. Patience, in turn, allows us to develop a wholeness, a completeness, lacking nothing. This isn't about ignoring pain or pretending everything is fine; it’s about seeing beyond the immediate suffering to the ultimate purpose. It's about trusting that God is using the trials to shape us into the image of Christ. By embracing these challenges with joy, we acknowledge God’s sovereignty and find peace in His process. This perspective shifts our focus from the difficulty itself to the eternal reward of a strengthened faith and a more Christ-like character. We are reminded that the goal isn’t to avoid trials, but to navigate them with a heart of gratitude and a mind fixed on the promises of God.
