2027-01-02.versiculo: Galatians 2:16 KJV: "Knowing that a man is not justified by the works of the law, but by the faith of Jesus Christ, even we have believed in Jesus Christ, that we might be justified by the faith of Christ, and not by the works of the law: for by the works of the law shall no flesh be justified."
2027-01-02.reflexion: Today's verse, Galatians 2:16, strikes at the heart of the Gospel. It declares that justification, or being declared righteous in God's eyes, is not achieved through our own efforts, our adherence to the Law, or our good works. Instead, it is by faith in Jesus Christ. The Apostle Paul emphasizes the futility of trying to earn our salvation. We cannot work our way into heaven. The Law, while good and holy, reveals our sinfulness and our inability to perfectly obey God. The beauty of the Gospel is that justification is a gift, freely given to those who believe in Jesus. This faith is not merely intellectual assent, but a trust, a reliance, and a surrender to Christ. It is a recognition that we are utterly dependent on His sacrifice on the cross for our forgiveness and reconciliation with God. This verse challenges us to examine where our hope for salvation lies. Are we trusting in our own performance, or are we resting in the finished work of Christ? The Gospel message is clear: by faith in Jesus Christ alone, we are justified and made right with God. This is the foundation of our relationship with Him, and the source of our eternal hope.

para_meditar.texto: Therefore we conclude that a man is justified by faith without the deeds of the law.
For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast.
For by one offering he hath perfected for ever them that are sanctified.

2027-01-02.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the precious gift of salvation through faith in Jesus Christ. I confess that I often try to earn your favor through my actions, but I know that true righteousness comes only from you. Help me to surrender my pride and fully trust in the finished work of Jesus on the cross. Open my heart to receive your grace with a grateful spirit, and may my life be a testament to the saving power of your love. Help me to understand the depth of your grace and to live each day in gratitude for your forgiveness. Grant me the strength to walk in faith, trusting in your promises and seeking to glorify you in all I do. Remove any doubt or fear, and fill me with the peace that surpasses all understanding. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-03.versiculo: Luke 11:9-10 KJV: "And I say unto you, Ask, and it shall be given you; seek, and ye shall find; knock, and it shall be opened unto you. For every one that asketh receiveth; and he that seeketh findeth; and to him that knocketh it shall be opened."
2027-01-03.reflexion: Today's passage, Luke 11:9-10, is a powerful reminder of the accessibility of God and the efficacy of prayer. Jesus encourages us to be persistent and bold in our requests, promising that our efforts will be rewarded. The verbs 'ask,' 'seek,' and 'knock' imply a progression of faith and dedication. Asking is the initial step, the expression of our need. Seeking involves actively pursuing God's will and guidance, diligently searching for answers. Knocking signifies perseverance and a refusal to give up, even when faced with obstacles or apparent silence. The promise is clear: those who ask will receive, those who seek will find, and those who knock will have the door opened. This is not a guarantee of instant gratification, but rather an assurance that God hears our prayers and responds according to His perfect will. It is an invitation to a deeper relationship with Him, built on trust and unwavering faith. We are called to be persistent in prayer, not because we need to convince God, but because prayer transforms us, aligning our hearts with His and preparing us to receive His blessings. This passage encourages us to approach God with confidence, knowing that He is a loving Father who desires to give good gifts to His children.

para_meditar.texto: Ask, and it shall be given you; seek, and ye shall find; knock, and it shall be opened unto you:
If any of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God, that giveth to all men liberally, and upbraideth not; and it shall be given him.
Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known unto God.

2027-01-03.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You today with hearts full of gratitude for Your unwavering love and promise. We thank You for the assurance that when we ask, seek, and knock, You will hear and answer. We confess that at times, we become discouraged and give up easily. Forgive us for our lack of faith and our tendency to doubt Your goodness. Help us to be persistent in prayer, to approach You with boldness and confidence, knowing that You are a loving Father who desires to give us good gifts. Grant us the wisdom to discern Your will and the strength to persevere through challenges. Teach us to trust in Your timing and to find comfort in Your presence. Guide us to seek You in all things, to be open to Your leading, and to live a life that reflects Your glory. We pray for all the needs in our lives, believing that You will provide. We ask for healing, provision, and guidance in all areas. Thank You for answering our prayers, even before we ask. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-04.versiculo: Luke 22:19-20 KJV: "And he took bread, and gave thanks, and brake it, and gave unto them, saying, This is my body which is given for you: this do in remembrance of me. Likewise also the cup after supper, saying, This cup is the new testament in my blood, which is shed for you."
2027-01-04.reflexion: Today's passage from Luke offers a profound meditation on the institution of the Lord's Supper, a sacred act of remembrance and communion. Jesus, on the eve of His crucifixion, takes bread and gives thanks, breaking it and offering it to His disciples, declaring it to be His body, given for them. He then takes the cup, representing the new covenant in His blood, shed for their redemption. This act is not merely a symbolic gesture; it is a powerful embodiment of Christ's sacrifice and the covenant He established with humanity. We are called to partake in this sacrament, not just as a ritual, but as a means of actively remembering Christ’s sacrifice and the love He demonstrated on the cross. To partake is to acknowledge our sin and our dependence on His grace. It is a commitment to live a life of faith, obedience, and love, mirroring the selflessness of Jesus. Through the Lord’s Supper, we are reminded of the magnitude of God's love and the price paid for our salvation, drawing us closer to Him and unifying us with other believers. The act encourages us to reflect on our own lives, our relationships with others, and our commitment to living a life worthy of the sacrifice made for us.

para_meditar.texto: And when he had given thanks, he brake it, and said, Take, eat: this is my body, which is broken for you: this do in remembrance of me.

Then Jesus said unto them, Verily, verily, I say unto you, Except ye eat the flesh of the Son of man, and drink his blood, ye have no life in you. Whoso eateth my flesh, and drinketh my blood, hath eternal life; and I will raise him up at the last day. For my flesh is meat indeed, and my blood is drink indeed. He that eateth my flesh, and drinketh my blood, dwelleth in me, and I in him.
How much more shall the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered himself without spot to God, purge your conscience from dead works to serve the living God?

2027-01-04.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with hearts full of gratitude for the sacrifice of your Son, Jesus Christ. Thank you for the bread of life and the cup of salvation, symbols of His broken body and shed blood, which provide atonement for our sins. We confess our need for your grace and mercy, and we ask for the Holy Spirit to guide us as we reflect on this profound mystery. Help us to remember the immense love you have for us and to live lives worthy of the sacrifice made for our redemption. Grant us a deeper understanding of your covenant and a renewed commitment to obedience and love. Unite us in fellowship and strengthen our faith as we partake in the Lord's Supper, drawing us closer to you and to each other. May we always remember and never forget, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-05.versiculo: Romans 11:6 KJV: "And if by grace, then is it no more of works: otherwise grace is no more grace. But if it be of works, then is it no more grace: otherwise work is no more work."
2027-01-05.reflexion: Romans 11:6 lays bare the fundamental nature of salvation: it is either by grace or by works, but not both. The Apostle Paul argues that if salvation is by grace, then it cannot be earned through our own efforts or deeds. Conversely, if we believe we can earn God's favor through our actions, then grace, which is unmerited favor, is rendered meaningless. This verse challenges us to examine the foundation of our faith. Are we trusting in our own righteousness, our adherence to rules and rituals, or are we fully relying on the grace of God provided through the sacrifice of Jesus Christ? The implications are profound. True grace demands humility, recognizing our utter dependence on God's love and mercy. It frees us from the burden of trying to earn our salvation and allows us to live in the security of knowing that we are accepted and loved, not because of what we do, but because of what Christ has done for us. This understanding transforms our relationship with God, fostering gratitude and a desire to serve Him, not out of obligation, but out of love and appreciation for His immeasurable gift.

para_meditar.texto: For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast.
Not by works of righteousness which we have done, but according to his mercy he saved us, by the washing of regeneration, and renewing of the Holy Ghost;
I do not frustrate the grace of God: for if righteousness come by the law, then Christ is dead in vain.

2027-01-05.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today acknowledging my complete dependence on Your grace. I confess that I often try to earn Your favor through my own efforts, forgetting that salvation is a free gift offered through Jesus Christ. Forgive me for my pride and my tendency to rely on my own works. Help me to fully embrace the truth that I am saved by grace, through faith, and not by anything I can do. Grant me the humility to accept Your love and mercy without reservation. Open my heart to the boundless grace you offer, and help me to live a life that reflects my gratitude for this incredible gift. Fill me with the Holy Spirit, so that I may serve You with a heart full of love and joy, not out of obligation, but out of a deep and abiding appreciation for Your sacrifice. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-06.versiculo: Philippians 3:10 KJV: "That I may know him, and the power of his resurrection, and the fellowship of his sufferings, being made conformable unto his death;"
2027-01-06.reflexion: Today's verse, Philippians 3:10, unveils the heart's deepest desire of the Apostle Paul: to know Christ intimately. This isn't a superficial acquaintance, but a profound understanding of Him, encompassing the power of His resurrection, the fellowship of His sufferings, and conformity to His death. Paul's yearning highlights a crucial truth: true knowledge of Christ is not just intellectual, but experiential. To 'know Him' involves experiencing the transformative power of His resurrection in our daily lives. It means walking in the power that overcame death, and applying that power to overcome the struggles we face. Moreover, Paul embraces 'the fellowship of His sufferings.' This signifies a willingness to share in Christ's pain, to identify with those who suffer, and to understand the depths of God's love through empathy and compassion. It’s a call to sacrifice, to put aside our own comfort and convenience for the sake of others and the advancement of the Gospel. Finally, 'being made conformable unto his death' speaks to the ultimate surrender of our will to God’s. It is a daily dying to self, a putting to death of our sinful nature, and a living in alignment with Christ’s example. This verse challenges us to move beyond a casual faith and to embrace a life of deeper devotion, seeking to know Christ not just in our minds, but in our hearts, in our actions, and in our very beings.

para_meditar.texto: And if children, then heirs; heirs of God, and joint-heirs with Christ; if so be that we suffer with him, that we may be also glorified together.
Always bearing about in the body the dying of the Lord Jesus, that the life also of Jesus might be made manifest in our body.
But rejoice, inasmuch as ye are partakers of Christ's sufferings; that, when his glory shall be revealed, ye may be glad also with exceeding joy.

2027-01-06.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before You today with a heart that longs to know You more deeply. Help me to experience the power of Christ's resurrection in every area of my life, to overcome the trials and tribulations I face with His strength and grace. Grant me the humility to embrace the fellowship of His sufferings, that I may learn to love and serve others as He did. Guide me to conform to His death, to die daily to my own desires and to live a life that is pleasing to You. Open my eyes to see Your will and give me the courage to follow Your path, even when it's difficult. Fill me with Your Spirit, that I may live a life reflecting Your love and mercy. Thank You for the sacrifice of Jesus, which makes all this possible. I give You all the glory, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-07.versiculo: 2 Peter 3:13 KJV: "Nevertheless we, according to his promise, look for new heavens and a new earth, wherein dwelleth righteousness."
2027-01-07.reflexion: Today's verse, 2 Peter 3:13, offers a powerful vision of hope: "Nevertheless we, according to his promise, look for new heavens and a new earth, wherein dwelleth righteousness." This verse speaks to the core of our Christian faith, painting a picture of a future transformed by God's grace. The 'new heavens and a new earth' represent more than just a change in scenery; they signify a complete renewal, a restoration of all things to their intended perfection, free from the taint of sin and suffering. This promise is not based on our own efforts, but on God's unwavering faithfulness. He has promised this new creation, and we can trust that He will fulfill His word. The phrase "wherein dwelleth righteousness" is crucial. It tells us that this new creation will be characterized by perfect justice, holiness, and integrity. Every aspect of life will be aligned with God's will. This should motivate us to live righteously in the present. If we are looking forward to a world where righteousness dwells, we should actively pursue righteousness in our daily lives. We should strive to reflect the character of God in our thoughts, words, and deeds, knowing that we are preparing ourselves for the glorious future He has promised.

para_meditar.texto: For, behold, I create new heavens and a new earth: and the former shall not be remembered, nor come into mind.
And I saw a new heaven and a new earth: for the first heaven and the first earth were passed away; and there was no more sea.
Because the creature itself also shall be delivered from the bondage of corruption into the glorious liberty of the children of God.

2027-01-07.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the glorious promise of a new heaven and a new earth, a place where righteousness dwells. Help us to fix our eyes on this hope, even amidst the trials and tribulations of this world. Grant us the grace to live lives that reflect your character, striving for holiness and justice in all that we do. Give us the strength to resist the temptations that draw us away from your path, and fill us with a longing for the day when we will dwell in your perfect presence. Guide us to be faithful witnesses of your love and mercy, sharing the good news of salvation with those around us. May our lives be a testament to the transformative power of your grace, and may we eagerly await the fulfillment of your promises. We thank you for your unwavering love and faithfulness, and for the hope that sustains us. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-08.versiculo: Romans 11:29 KJV: "For the gifts and calling of God are without repentance."
2027-01-08.reflexion: Today's verse, Romans 11:29, offers a profound reassurance about God's unwavering commitment to His promises. The Apostle Paul declares that God's gifts and calling are 'without repentance,' meaning He does not change His mind or revoke His decisions. This truth speaks volumes about God's character: He is faithful, steadfast, and true to His word. This verse is particularly relevant in the context of Romans 9-11, where Paul addresses the question of Israel's rejection of the Gospel. Even though many Israelites had not embraced Jesus, God's covenant with them remained. His promises to Abraham and his descendants would not be nullified. This principle applies to us as well. When God calls us, when He bestows gifts upon us, and when He makes promises, He is committed to seeing them through. This knowledge should fill us with immense hope and confidence. We can trust that God's plans for our lives are secure, even when we face difficulties or experience times of doubt. We can rest in the certainty that God's grace and His calling on our lives are irrevocable. Let us embrace this truth, knowing that God's faithfulness extends throughout all generations, and that His gifts to us are eternal and unchanging.

para_meditar.texto: God is not a man, that he should lie; neither the son of man, that he should repent: hath he said, and shall he not do it? or hath he spoken, and shall he not make it good?
That by two immutable things, in which it was impossible for God to lie, we might have a strong consolation, who have fled for refuge to lay hold upon the hope set before us:
My covenant will I not break, nor alter the thing that is gone out of my lips.

2027-01-08.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the unwavering nature of Your love and Your promises. Thank You that Your gifts and Your calling upon our lives are without repentance. Grant us the faith to trust in Your perfect plan, even when we don't understand it. Help us to remember that You are faithful, and Your Word is true. Give us the strength to persevere, knowing that You are always working for our good. Fill us with a deep sense of hope and confidence in Your unchanging character. May we live each day in the assurance that You will never forsake us. We ask for Your guidance and wisdom as we navigate life's challenges, trusting that You will see us through. We commit our lives into Your loving hands, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-09.versiculo: Mark 2:17 KJV: "When Jesus heard it, he saith unto them, They that are whole have no need of the physician, but they that are sick: I came not to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance."
2027-01-09.reflexion: Today's verse speaks volumes about the heart of Jesus. He clarifies His mission: He came not for the self-righteous, those who believe they have no need of a physician (spiritual healing), but for the sick, those who recognize their need for repentance and forgiveness. This challenges our own self-perception. Are we like the Pharisees, believing we are whole and therefore don't need Jesus? Or do we humbly admit our spiritual sickness, our need for His grace and mercy? The verse reminds us that Jesus' invitation is for everyone, especially those who feel lost, broken, and burdened by their sins. It's a call to examine our hearts and see if we are truly seeking His healing touch. The emphasis is not on our worthiness, but on our need. The physician comes for the sick, the healer for the wounded. This passage is a testament to the boundless love and compassion of our Savior, who seeks out the lost and offers them new life.

para_meditar.texto: But he was wounded for our transgressions, he was bruised for our iniquities: the chastisement of our peace was upon him; and with his stripes we are healed.
But God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.
If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness.

2027-01-09.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the profound truth revealed in Mark 2:17. Thank you for sending Jesus, the Great Physician, to heal our spiritual sickness. Lord, help me to recognize my need for you, to confess my sins, and to embrace your forgiveness and grace. Open my eyes to see the areas in my life where I am still struggling and help me surrender those areas to your loving care. Grant me the humility to seek your healing touch and the strength to walk in repentance. Help me to never forget that Jesus came for sinners, and that your love is extended to all, regardless of their past. Fill my heart with gratitude for your sacrifice and guide me to live a life that reflects your love and mercy. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-10.versiculo: Ephesians 4:1 KJV: "I therefore, the prisoner of the Lord, beseech you that ye walk worthy of the vocation wherewith ye are called,"
2027-01-10.reflexion: Today's verse, Ephesians 4:1, is a powerful call to action for every believer. Paul, a prisoner for the sake of the gospel, implores us to 'walk worthy' of our calling. This isn't merely a suggestion; it's a plea, born from his deep love for the church and his understanding of the high calling we have in Christ. 'Walking worthy' means living in a manner that reflects the grace, mercy, and love we have received. It's about aligning our actions, thoughts, and words with the character of Christ. It demands a constant self-examination, a willingness to deny ourselves, and a commitment to follow the teachings of Jesus. This worthy walk is not a burden, but a privilege. It is a journey of transformation, where we are constantly being molded into the image of Christ. It requires humility, recognizing our dependence on God, and a persistent pursuit of holiness. It’s about living in unity with other believers, loving our enemies, and spreading the good news of the Gospel. It is the embodiment of a life lived in obedience, gratitude, and purpose, reflecting the light of Christ in a world desperately in need of hope.

para_meditar.texto: Only let your conversation be as it becometh the gospel of Christ: that whether I come and see you, or else be absent, I may hear of your affairs, that ye stand fast in one spirit, with one mind striving together for the faith of the gospel;
Put on therefore, as the elect of God, holy and beloved, bowels of mercies, kindness, humbleness of mind, meekness, longsuffering;
Having your conversation honest among the Gentiles: that, whereas they speak against you as evildoers, they may by your good works, which they shall behold, glorify God in the day of visitation.

2027-01-10.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today, humbled by the profound words of Ephesians 4:1. I pray for the grace to walk worthy of the calling you have placed upon my life. Help me to reflect Your love, mercy, and grace in all that I do and say. Grant me the strength to deny myself, to take up my cross daily, and to follow in the footsteps of Jesus. Guide me to live in unity with my brothers and sisters in Christ, to love my enemies, and to be a beacon of hope in a dark world. Open my eyes to see the opportunities to serve You and to spread the good news of the Gospel. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, that I may be transformed into the image of Christ. I ask all these things, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-11.versiculo: Acts 26:18 KJV: "To open their eyes, and to turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan unto God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins, and inheritance among them which are sanctified by faith that is in me."
2027-01-11.reflexion: The words of Acts 26:18 are a powerful declaration of the transformative work of the Gospel. Paul, speaking before King Agrippa, outlines the core mission given to him by Christ: to open the eyes of the Gentiles, turning them from the darkness of sin and the dominion of Satan to the radiant light of God. This turning involves a radical shift in allegiance, from the realm of darkness to the Kingdom of God. The promise held out is nothing less than forgiveness of sins and an inheritance among those sanctified by faith in Christ. This verse encapsulates the essence of salvation. It speaks of liberation from the bondage of sin and the devil, offering the gift of new sight, a new direction, and a new eternal inheritance. To have our eyes opened means to understand the truth of God's love and plan for us. It means to see our need for a Savior and to embrace the grace offered through Jesus Christ. The inheritance speaks of the eternal life and fellowship with God promised to all who believe. It reminds us of the cost of our redemption and the glorious future that awaits us. Let us embrace this truth and live in the hope of the inheritance that is ours through faith.

para_meditar.texto: Then spake Jesus again unto them, saying, I am the light of the world: he that followeth me shall not walk in darkness, but shall have the light of life.
The eyes of your understanding being enlightened; that ye may know what is the hope of his calling, and what the riches of the glory of his inheritance in the saints.
Who hath delivered us from the power of darkness, and hath translated us into the kingdom of his dear Son: In whom we have redemption through his blood, even the forgiveness of sins.

2027-01-11.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank You for the light of the Gospel, which shines into our hearts and minds. We praise You for opening our eyes to see the truth, turning us from the darkness of sin to the glorious light of Your presence. We confess that we have often walked in darkness, blinded by the deceitfulness of sin. Forgive us for the times we have chosen to remain in the shadows. Help us to understand the depth of Your love and the magnitude of the sacrifice Jesus made for us on the cross. Give us strength to resist the temptations of the enemy and to walk in the light of Your truth. Grant us a deeper understanding of the inheritance we have been given, and help us to live each day in anticipation of the eternal life that awaits us. Fill us with faith, hope, and love, so that we may be a light to others in this dark world. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-12.versiculo: John 6:51 KJV: "I am the living bread which came down from heaven: if any man eat of this bread, he shall live for ever: and the bread that I will give is my flesh, which I will give for the life of the world."
2027-01-12.reflexion: Today's verse, John 6:51, presents a profound and challenging truth. Jesus declares Himself the 'living bread' come down from heaven, offering eternal life to those who partake of Him. This isn't a mere metaphor; Jesus explicitly states that His flesh, which He will give for the life of the world, is the means of this eternal sustenance. This is a radical claim, demanding a complete reevaluation of our understanding of life, death, and our relationship with God. To 'eat' of this bread, to truly receive Jesus, requires more than just intellectual assent; it demands a wholehearted embrace of His teachings, a trust in His sacrifice, and a daily communion with Him. It's about allowing Him to nourish our spirits, to transform our hearts, and to guide our lives. The world offers many 'breads' – fleeting pleasures, material possessions, and worldly ambitions – that ultimately leave us hungry and unfulfilled. Only Jesus, the Bread of Life, can truly satisfy our deepest longings and grant us the promise of eternal life. This verse invites us to examine our own spiritual hunger. Are we truly seeking the Bread of Life, or are we content with the substitutes the world offers? Let us actively pursue a deeper relationship with Jesus, feasting on His Word and receiving His grace, that we may truly live forever.

para_meditar.texto: O taste and see that the Lord is good: blessed is the man that trusteth in him.

Wherefore do ye spend money for that which is not bread? and your labour for that which satisfieth not? hearken diligently unto me, and eat ye that which is good, and let your soul delight itself in fatness.
And Jesus said unto them, I am the bread of life: he that cometh to me shall never hunger; and he that believeth on me shall never thirst.

2027-01-12.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for sending your Son, Jesus Christ, the Bread of Life, to nourish us and offer us eternal life. We confess our need for Him, and we open our hearts to receive His grace and love. Help us to truly 'eat' of this bread, to embrace Your teachings, and to trust in Your sacrifice for us. Guide us away from the fleeting pleasures of this world and direct us towards the fulfillment that comes from a deep relationship with You. Grant us the wisdom to recognize the false bread and the strength to choose You every day. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, and guide us to live a life that honors you. May we always seek You and find our satisfaction in You. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-13.versiculo: 3 John 1:11 KJV: "Beloved, follow not that which is evil, but that which is good. He that doeth good is of God: but he that doeth evil hath not seen God."
2027-01-13.reflexion:
Today's verse, 3 John 1:11, is a powerful call to action. It's a simple, yet profound directive: choose good and shun evil. This isn't just a passive suggestion; it's an active command. The writer, likely the Apostle John, reminds us that our actions have consequences, revealing our true spiritual state. Those who consistently choose good are demonstrably 'of God,' reflecting His character and will. Conversely, those who embrace evil demonstrate a lack of genuine relationship with Him. 

This verse challenges us to examine our lives. Are we truly striving for what is good, or are we making compromises? Are our actions a reflection of God's love, grace, and truth? It's not about perfection, but about direction. We are called to a life of intentionality, actively pursuing goodness in thought, word, and deed. This requires vigilance, discernment, and a willingness to step away from anything that contradicts God's nature. Let us strive to be known by our good works, reflecting the light of Christ to a world desperately in need of it.

para_meditar.texto: Trust in the Lord with all thine heart; and lean not unto thine own understanding. In all thy ways acknowledge him, and he shall direct thy paths.
And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.
And let us not be weary in well doing: for in due season we shall reap, if we faint not.

2027-01-13.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You today, seeking Your guidance. Help us to discern between good and evil in all aspects of our lives. Grant us the strength to choose good consistently, even when it is difficult. Open our eyes to the ways we may be falling short of Your will, and give us the courage to turn away from anything that displeases You. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, so that our actions may reflect Your love, grace, and truth to a world in need. Guide us to walk in Your ways, and to be a light for others. We thank You for Your love and for the gift of eternal life. We commit our lives to You, and ask for Your continued guidance, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-14.versiculo: 2 Timothy 1:9 KJV: "Who hath saved us, and called us with an holy calling, not according to our works, but according to his own purpose and grace, which was given us in Christ Jesus before the world began,"
2027-01-14.reflexion: Today's verse from 2 Timothy 1:9, a cornerstone of our faith, reminds us of the profound truth of God's saving grace. The passage highlights that our salvation isn't earned through our actions, but is a gift from God, bestowed upon us through His purpose and grace. This grace was given to us in Christ Jesus even before the world began. This underscores the eternal nature of God's plan for redemption. We are called with a holy calling, a divine invitation to a life of purpose and righteousness. This calling is not based on our inherent worthiness, which is non-existent, but solely on God's character. The verse encourages us to embrace this grace, recognizing that our salvation is secure in Christ. It is a call to live a life worthy of the calling we have received, a life of gratitude, obedience, and service. We are reminded to lean into the grace that has been freely given, and to trust in God's unwavering love and provision. This verse should fill us with hope and fuel our desire to live a life pleasing to God.

para_meditar.texto: For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast.
And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to his purpose.
Not by works of righteousness which we have done, but according to his mercy he saved us, by the washing of regeneration, and renewing of the Holy Ghost;

2027-01-14.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You today, humbled by the magnitude of Your grace. We thank You for saving us and calling us with a holy calling, not according to our own merit, but according to Your divine purpose. Help us to fully grasp the depth of Your love, a love that was planned before the world began. Help us to live lives worthy of this calling, filled with gratitude, obedience, and a desire to serve You. Grant us the strength to resist temptation and to walk in the light of Your truth. Guide us in our journey, and make us instruments of Your peace and love. Help us to share this good news with others, that they too may experience the joy of salvation. Thank You for the gift of Your Son, Jesus Christ, our Lord and Savior, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-15.versiculo: Luke 11:28 KJV: "But he said, Yea rather, blessed are they that hear the word of God, and keep it."
2027-01-15.reflexion: Today's verse, Luke 11:28, offers a profound insight into true blessedness. The woman who exclaimed about the blessedness of Jesus' mother, likely based on the cultural reverence for motherhood, receives a correction from Jesus. He elevates the focus from physical proximity or familial ties to a deeper spiritual reality. Jesus doesn't deny the blessing of the mother, but redirects the emphasis. He states that those who hear the word of God and keep it are truly blessed. This speaks to the active engagement required in our faith. It's not enough to simply hear the teachings of God; we must internalize them, understand them, and most importantly, live them out. This is a call to action, a challenge to embody the principles of the Kingdom of God in our daily lives. It's about obedience, faith, and the consistent application of God's word in every aspect of our being. This verse encourages us to move beyond passive listening and embrace an active, obedient relationship with God. The true blessing comes from the transformation that occurs when we allow God's word to shape our hearts, minds, and actions. It’s a reminder that hearing and doing are intertwined and essential components of a life truly blessed by God.

para_meditar.texto: But be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving your own selves.
And Moses called all Israel, and said unto them, Hear, O Israel, the statutes and judgments which I speak in your ears this day, that ye may learn them, and keep, and do them.
Jesus answered and said unto him, If a man love me, he will keep my words: and my Father will love him, and we will come unto him, and make our abode with him.

2027-01-15.oracion: Lord, thank you for your word, which is a lamp unto my feet and a light unto my path. Help me not only to hear your word, but also to understand it and to live it out in every area of my life. Grant me the strength and the wisdom to obey your commandments and to follow in your footsteps. Help me to be a doer of your word, not just a hearer, so that I may experience the fullness of your blessings. Fill my heart with a desire to know you more deeply and to please you in all that I do. Remove any distractions that prevent me from focusing on your teachings. Guide me, strengthen me, and help me to be a faithful disciple. May my life be a testament to your grace and mercy, shining your light to all those around me. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-16.versiculo: 1 Thessalonians 1:9-10 KJV: "For they themselves shew of us what manner of entering in we had unto you, and how ye turned to God from idols to serve the living and true God; And to wait for his Son from heaven, whom he raised from the dead, even Jesus, which delivered us from the wrath to come."
2027-01-16.reflexion: Today's passage, 1 Thessalonians 1:9-10, offers a powerful glimpse into the transformative power of the Gospel. The Thessalonians' conversion is presented as a model: they turned 'to God from idols' and began 'to serve the living and true God.' This act of turning is a complete redirection of life, a renunciation of false worship and a wholehearted embrace of the one true God. It signifies a radical shift in allegiance, from the ephemeral and empty promises of idols to the eternal and fulfilling presence of God. Furthermore, the passage highlights the Thessalonians' active waiting for the return of Jesus. This 'waiting' isn't passive; it's a posture of eager anticipation, reflecting a vibrant faith and a confident hope in the promise of salvation. They understood that Jesus' resurrection was the guarantee of their own deliverance 'from the wrath to come.' This hope fueled their lives, shaping their actions, and influencing their interactions with others. This passage challenges us to examine our own lives. Have we turned away from the idols of our modern world – materialism, self-reliance, and worldly pursuits? Are we actively serving God, or are we lukewarm in our faith? Are we eagerly awaiting the return of Christ, or have we become complacent? Let us strive to emulate the Thessalonians' example, turning from the false gods and embracing the living God, while living in hopeful anticipation of Christ's return.

para_meditar.texto: That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved.
For our conversation is in heaven; from whence also we look for the Saviour, the Lord Jesus Christ:
He that hath the Son hath life; and he that hath not the Son of God hath not life.

2027-01-16.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the transformative power of your love and grace. Thank you for calling us out of darkness and into your marvelous light. Help us to turn away from the idols that tempt us and lead us astray. Grant us the strength to serve you wholeheartedly, with a pure heart and a willing spirit. Fill us with the eager anticipation of Christ's return, and help us live in a manner worthy of your calling. May we be ever mindful of the hope we have in you, and may this hope shape our thoughts, words, and actions. May we be beacons of light in a world that desperately needs your truth. We ask for your guidance and strength, that we may remain steadfast in our faith, trusting in your promises, and living in the hope of eternal life. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-17.versiculo: 1 John 4:16 KJV: "And we have known and believed the love that God hath to us. God is love; and he that dwelleth in love dwelleth in God, and God in him."
2027-01-17.reflexion:
Today's verse, 1 John 4:16, is a cornerstone of Christian understanding. It doesn't just say that God *has* love; it declares that God *is* love. This is a profound statement, defining the very essence of the divine. To truly grasp this truth, we must first acknowledge the love God has shown to us. Through the sacrifice of Jesus Christ, we see the ultimate expression of this love, a love that transcends our imperfections and offers forgiveness and eternal life.

To dwell in love, as the verse states, is to dwell in God, and for God to dwell in us. This is a reciprocal relationship. It's not merely about feeling affectionate; it’s about living out the principles of love – kindness, patience, forgiveness, and selflessness. It means aligning our thoughts, words, and actions with the character of God. When we choose to love others, even those who are difficult, we are reflecting the image of God and allowing His love to flow through us. This transforms not only our own lives but also the lives of those around us, creating a ripple effect of grace and compassion. It is a constant invitation to abide in the presence of God, experiencing His peace and joy, and living a life that glorifies Him.

para_meditar.texto: But God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.

Charity suffereth long, and is kind; charity envieth not; charity vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up, Doth not behave itself unseemly, seeketh not her own, is not easily provoked, thinketh no evil; Rejoiceth not in iniquity, but rejoiceth in the truth; Beareth all things, believeth all things, hopeth all things, endureth all things.
This is my commandment, That ye love one another, as I have loved you.

2027-01-17.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for revealing Your love to us, a love so profound that it defines Your very nature. Help us to understand and believe in this incredible love. Grant us the grace to dwell in love, to embody kindness, patience, and forgiveness in our daily lives. May we love others as You have loved us, reflecting Your image in all that we do. Fill our hearts with Your love, so that we may be channels of Your grace and compassion to a world in need. Strengthen us to overcome selfishness and embrace the selfless love of Christ. Guide us to live a life that honors You, a life where Your love shines brightly. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-18.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 13:1 KJV: "Though I speak with the tongues of men and of angels, and have not charity, I am become as sounding brass, or a tinkling cymbal."
2027-01-18.reflexion: Today's verse, 1 Corinthians 13:1, plunges us into the heart of what truly matters: love. Paul eloquently declares that even the most impressive spiritual gifts, like speaking in tongues (languages of men and angels!), are worthless without love (charity). He uses vivid imagery, comparing a person lacking love to a noisy, empty instrument – sounding brass or a tinkling cymbal. The point is clear: eloquence and outward displays of spirituality, no matter how impressive, are mere noise if they lack the genuine, self-sacrificing love that defines the Christian faith. This verse challenges us to examine our own hearts. Are we focused on performing, on impressing others with our abilities and knowledge? Or are we cultivating the kind of love that desires the good of others, that is patient, kind, and selfless? It's a call to prioritize love above all else, recognizing that it is the foundation upon which all other spiritual gifts find their true value and purpose. Without love, our actions become hollow and our words, meaningless. Let us strive to embody the essence of love, making it the guiding principle of our lives and interactions.

para_meditar.texto: He that loveth not knoweth not God; for God is love.
Let love be without dissimulation. Abhor that which is evil; cleave to that which is good.
And above all these things put on charity, which is the bond of perfectness.

2027-01-18.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today, humbled by the truth of 1 Corinthians 13:1. We confess that we often prioritize outward displays of faith over the genuine love that you command. Forgive us for the times we have sought recognition, for the times we have failed to love our neighbor as ourselves. Help us to understand that without love, all our efforts are in vain. Fill our hearts with your love, a love that is patient, kind, and selfless. Help us to love others as you have loved us, unconditionally and sacrificially. Give us the strength to speak with love, to act with love, and to live a life that reflects your love to the world. Open our eyes to see the needs of those around us and give us the courage to meet those needs with compassion and grace. May your love be the driving force behind all that we do, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-19.versiculo: Luke 6:46-47 KJV: "And why call ye me, Lord, Lord, and do not the things which I say? Whosoever cometh to me, and heareth my sayings, and doeth them, I will shew you to whom he is like:"
2027-01-19.reflexion:
Today's passage from Luke 6:46-47 challenges us to examine the authenticity of our faith. Jesus poses a profound question: Why do we call Him Lord, yet fail to act upon His teachings? It's easy to profess our faith with our lips, to sing hymns and participate in religious rituals. However, true discipleship extends far beyond the superficial. It demands a practical application of Christ’s words in our daily lives. 

Jesus emphasizes the importance of not only hearing His words but also doing them. He uses the analogy of a house built upon a rock, a sturdy foundation that withstands the storms. This illustrates that those who hear and obey the teachings of Jesus are like the wise builder. They are grounded in the truth and their faith will endure through trials and tribulations. Conversely, those who hear but do not act are likened to the foolish builder, whose house is built on sand, destined to crumble under pressure. This passage calls us to a deeper level of commitment, urging us to be doers of the word, not hearers only. Let us strive to live out our faith, building our lives on the solid foundation of Christ's teachings, so that we may weather any storm and stand firm in our devotion to Him.

para_meditar.texto: But be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving your own selves.
Not every one that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven; but he that doeth the will of my Father which is in heaven.
If ye love me, keep my commandments.

2027-01-19.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You with hearts full of gratitude for Your unwavering love and grace. We confess that we often fall short of living out Your word, and we are easily distracted by the cares of this world. Forgive us for the times we have called upon Your name without truly following Your teachings. Help us to be doers of Your word, not just hearers. Grant us the strength and discernment to apply Your wisdom to every aspect of our lives. Instill in us a desire to serve You with all our hearts, minds, and strength. Guide us to build our lives on the solid foundation of Your truth, so that we may stand firm in faith. Transform our hearts, Lord, and make us more like Jesus, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-20.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 1:2 KJV: "Unto the church of God which is at Corinth, to them that are sanctified in Christ Jesus, called to be saints, with all that in every place call upon the name of Jesus Christ our Lord, both their's and our's:"
2027-01-20.reflexion: The opening verse of Paul's first letter to the Corinthians, 1 Corinthians 1:2, sets the stage for a profound exploration of what it means to be a part of the church, to be sanctified in Christ Jesus, and to be called to be saints. Paul addresses this letter to the church of God at Corinth, a community known for its challenges and divisions. He acknowledges their sanctification, their being set apart for God through faith in Jesus Christ. This is not something earned but a gift, a divine act of grace. Being 'called to be saints' is not merely a title but a call to a life of holiness, reflecting the character of Christ. The verse extends beyond Corinth, encompassing all who call upon the name of Jesus Christ, acknowledging a universal fellowship of believers. This highlights the unity of the church, transcending geographical boundaries. The implications of this verse are far-reaching. It reminds us of our identity in Christ, the privilege of being set apart, and the responsibility to live a life worthy of our calling. It emphasizes the importance of fellowship and the interconnectedness of believers globally. It is a call to unity, holiness, and a life lived in the grace and love of God. We are not alone; we are part of a larger family, united by our shared faith in Jesus Christ.

para_meditar.texto: To all that be in Rome, beloved of God, called to be saints: Grace to you and peace from God our Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ.
Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, to the saints which are at Ephesus, and to the faithful in Christ Jesus:
But ye are a chosen generation, a royal priesthood, an holy nation, a peculiar people; that ye should shew forth the praises of him who hath called you out of darkness into his marvellous light:

2027-01-20.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with hearts full of gratitude for the gift of salvation and the privilege of being called saints. Thank you for sanctifying us through the precious blood of Jesus Christ. Help us to live lives worthy of our calling, reflecting your love and grace in all that we do. Grant us the strength to resist temptation and to grow in holiness, seeking to be more like Christ each day. Bless our fellowship with other believers, and unite us in the spirit of love and unity. May we always be mindful of those in every place who call upon your name, and may we strive to build up the body of Christ together. Guide us to share the good news of your love with others. We commit our lives to you, trusting in your guidance and provision. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-21.versiculo: Acts 3:26 KJV: "Unto you first God, having raised up his Son Jesus, sent him to bless you, in turning away every one of you from his iniquities."
2027-01-21.reflexion: Today's verse from Acts 3:26 presents a powerful message of salvation and blessing through Jesus Christ. Peter, in his sermon, highlights that God's primary purpose in raising Jesus was to bless those who would turn from their sins. This verse emphasizes the priority of the Gospel message: it was first proclaimed to the Jews, but it extends to all. The blessing comes not just in forgiveness, but also in a turning away from sin. This act of turning, of repentance, is crucial. It's not merely a passive acknowledgement of wrongdoing, but a conscious decision to change direction, to walk away from the path of iniquity and embrace God's will. The raising of Jesus serves as the foundation for this blessing. His resurrection is the ultimate proof of God's power and His victory over sin and death. This resurrection offers hope and the promise of new life to all who believe. The focus on turning away from iniquities is a call to both receive the blessing and to actively participate in the process of sanctification. It encourages us to continually examine our lives, seeking God's guidance and striving to live in accordance with His teachings. This is not a one-time event, but a continuous journey of growth in faith and obedience.

para_meditar.texto: But now being made free from sin, and become servants to God, ye have your fruit unto holiness, and the end everlasting life.
Therefore if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature: old things are passed away; behold, all things are become new.
If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness.

2027-01-21.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for sending Your Son, Jesus, to bless us and to turn us away from our iniquities. We acknowledge our sins and ask for Your forgiveness. Help us to embrace the blessing of a new life in Christ, and empower us to turn away from the things that displease You. Grant us the strength to walk in Your ways, to live a life of holiness, and to share the good news of salvation with others. May we continually seek Your guidance and allow Your Holy Spirit to transform us from the inside out. Fill us with Your love, Your grace, and Your peace, and help us to reflect Your light in all that we do. We thank You for the promise of eternal life, and we pray for the courage to live a life that honors You. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-22.versiculo: 1 Timothy 1:16 KJV: "Howbeit for this cause I obtained mercy, that in me first Jesus Christ might shew forth all longsuffering, for a pattern to them which should hereafter believe on him to life everlasting."
2027-01-22.reflexion: The Apostle Paul, in his letter to Timothy, offers a profound testament to God's grace and longsuffering in 1 Timothy 1:16. He acknowledges that he, a former persecutor of the church, obtained mercy. This wasn't merely a casual forgiveness; it was a deliberate act of God, designed to showcase His infinite patience and grace. Paul's transformation from a fierce opponent of Christianity to its most zealous advocate served as a powerful example for all who would later believe. His life became a living testament to the transformative power of Christ, demonstrating that no one is beyond the reach of God's mercy. The verse emphasizes that God's longsuffering is not just an attribute; it is a demonstration, a 'pattern' for those who seek eternal life. Paul's story provides hope and encouragement, reminding us that our past mistakes do not define our future in Christ. It's a call to recognize the boundless nature of God's love and the opportunity for redemption that is available to all who believe. It reminds us that even the 'chief of sinners' can find salvation and become a beacon of hope for others.

para_meditar.texto: But God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.
For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast.
Let us therefore come boldly unto the throne of grace, that we may obtain mercy, and find grace to help in time of need.

2027-01-22.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for Your immeasurable mercy and grace. Thank You for the example of Paul, who found forgiveness and became a vessel for Your glory. Help me to understand the depth of Your longsuffering, and may I never take Your grace for granted. Grant me the strength to live a life worthy of Your calling, that I may also be a pattern of Your love to others. May I be bold in sharing the good news of the Gospel, knowing that You extend Your hand of mercy to all who call upon Your name. Guide me to trust in Your plan, even when I stumble, and to rely on Your grace daily. I pray that I may reflect Your love and compassion in every aspect of my life, drawing others closer to You, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-23.versiculo: Hebrews 6:1 KJV: "Therefore leaving the principles of the doctrine of Christ, let us go on unto perfection; not laying again the foundation of repentance from dead works, and of faith toward God,"
2027-01-23.reflexion: Today's verse calls us to move beyond the basics, to progress in our faith journey. It urges us to leave behind the elementary teachings and strive for spiritual maturity, for 'perfection'. The writer of Hebrews emphasizes the importance of not continually dwelling on the initial steps of faith: repentance and faith in God. While these are essential foundations, they are not the final destination. We are called to continually build upon these foundations, progressing towards a deeper understanding of Christ and a more intimate relationship with Him. This means actively seeking knowledge, growing in spiritual disciplines, and putting into practice the teachings we have received. It challenges us to evaluate where we are in our faith walk. Are we content with the elementary teachings, or are we actively seeking to grow and mature? The journey of faith is not a stagnant one; it requires constant effort, growth, and a willingness to embrace the fullness of God's grace.

para_meditar.texto: I press toward the mark for the prize of the high calling of God in Christ Jesus.
But grow in grace, and in the knowledge of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ. To him be glory both now and for ever. Amen.
As ye have therefore received Christ Jesus the Lord, so walk ye in him: Rooted and built up in him, and stablished in the faith, as ye have been taught, abounding therein with thanksgiving.

2027-01-23.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the foundation of faith you have laid in my life. Help me to not remain stagnant, but to continually strive for spiritual maturity. Give me the desire to learn more about you, to understand your Word more deeply, and to put your teachings into practice in my daily life. Grant me the strength to resist complacency and to embrace the challenges that come with growth. Guide me on this journey of faith, and help me to press on towards the prize of the high calling. Fill me with your grace and wisdom, and lead me closer to you each day. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-24.versiculo: Romans 5:12 KJV: "Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for that all have sinned:"
2027-01-24.reflexion: Today's verse, Romans 5:12, paints a stark picture of the human condition. It reveals the origin of sin and its devastating consequences: death. Through one man, Adam, sin entered the world, and with it, the reality of death. This isn't just physical death, but spiritual death – separation from God. The verse underscores the universal nature of sin; it affects every single human being. We are all born into a world tainted by sin, and we all fall short of God's glory. This truth should lead us to humility and a deep understanding of our need for a Savior. Recognizing our inherent sinfulness and the resulting death should drive us to the foot of the cross. It is only through faith in Jesus Christ, who paid the ultimate price for our sin, that we can find redemption and eternal life. The verse is a call to acknowledge our brokenness and embrace the gift of grace offered to us through the sacrifice of Jesus. It's a reminder of the gravity of sin, but also a beacon of hope, pointing us to the solution: Jesus.

para_meditar.texto: For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.
For all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God;
If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness.

2027-01-24.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You acknowledging our sinfulness and our need for Your grace. We recognize that, like all humanity, we are born into a world stained by sin and subject to death. We confess our shortcomings and our failures to live according to Your will. We thank You for sending Your Son, Jesus Christ, to take the punishment we deserved. We thank You for His sacrifice on the cross, which paid the price for our sins and opened the way to eternal life. Help us to continually turn to You, seeking forgiveness, strength, and guidance. Give us a heart that seeks after Your righteousness and a life that reflects Your love. May we live in the light of Your grace, sharing the good news of salvation with others. We pray for a deeper understanding of Your love and mercy and a greater desire to follow Your commandments. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-25.versiculo: 2 Corinthians 11:3 KJV: "But I fear, lest by any means, as the serpent beguiled Eve through his subtilty, so your minds should be corrupted from the simplicity that is in Christ."
2027-01-25.reflexion:
Today's verse serves as a stark warning against the subtle dangers that can corrupt our faith. Paul expresses his fear that the Corinthians, like Eve in the Garden of Eden, might be deceived by false teachings and stray from the pure and simple truth of Christ. The serpent's method was one of subtlety, twisting the truth and appealing to Eve's desires and doubts. Similarly, false teachers often use clever arguments, appealing to our intellect or emotional needs, to lead us astray. 

The 'simplicity that is in Christ' refers to the straightforward and unadulterated gospel message: that Christ died for our sins, was buried, and rose again. It's a message of grace, faith, and love. To maintain this simplicity, we must be vigilant. We must guard our hearts and minds against the subtle influences of the world, false doctrines, and our own sinful inclinations. Just as Eve was vulnerable to the serpent's whispers, we are vulnerable to the deceitful whispers of the enemy. We must cling to the truth of Scripture, seek discernment through prayer, and remain grounded in the love of Christ. Only then can we avoid being corrupted and maintain the purity of our faith.

para_meditar.texto: Keep thy heart with all diligence; for out of it are the issues of life.
The light of the body is the eye: if therefore thine eye be single, thy whole body shall be full of light.
Put on the whole armour of God, that ye may be able to stand against the wiles of the devil.

2027-01-25.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today humbled and aware of our vulnerability to deception. We pray for discernment, that we might recognize the subtle tactics of the enemy and not be led astray from the simplicity of the gospel. Help us to guard our hearts and minds, to cling to the truth of your Word, and to seek you diligently in prayer. Grant us the strength to resist temptation and to remain steadfast in our faith. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, that we may walk in your light and live lives pleasing to you. Guide us away from any false teachings or influences that would corrupt our minds. Protect us from the serpent's whispers and keep us focused on the love and grace found in Jesus Christ. We ask this in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-26.versiculo: 1 Timothy 3:16 KJV: "And without controversy great is the mystery of godliness: God was manifest in the flesh, justified in the Spirit, seen of angels, preached unto the Gentiles, believed on in the world, received up into glory."
2027-01-26.reflexion:
Today’s verse, 1 Timothy 3:16, unveils the profound mystery of godliness. It's a declaration of the central tenets of our faith, a summary of the gospel. The verse begins with the awe-inspiring statement that God manifested Himself in the flesh. This refers to the incarnation of Jesus Christ, the eternal Son of God taking on human form. He lived a sinless life, walked among us, and experienced the fullness of human existence. 

Next, we see that He was 'justified in the Spirit.' This speaks to the divine validation of Jesus's ministry, life, and ultimately, His sacrifice. The Holy Spirit bore witness to His righteousness. The verse continues to describe the witness of the angels, the preaching to the Gentiles, the belief throughout the world, and finally, the ascension into glory. Each of these phrases highlights different aspects of Christ's work and the impact of the gospel. It is a call to marvel at the incredible plan of redemption and to respond in faith and obedience. This verse is not just a statement; it is an invitation to contemplate the depth and breadth of God's love and grace. It encourages us to live lives that reflect the godliness we are called to.

para_meditar.texto: And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us, (and we beheld his glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father,) full of grace and truth.

Who, being in the form of God, thought it not robbery to be equal with God: But made himself of no reputation, and took upon him the form of a servant, and was made in the likeness of men: And being found in fashion as a man, he humbled himself, and became obedient unto death, even the death of the cross.

Who being the brightness of his glory, and the express image of his person, and upholding all things by the word of his power, when he had by himself purged our sins, sat down on the right hand of the Majesty on high.

2027-01-26.oracion: Heavenly Father, we stand in awe of the mystery of godliness, the profound truth revealed in Your Word. We are humbled by the incarnation of Your Son, Jesus Christ, who manifested Himself in the flesh, lived a perfect life, and offered Himself as a sacrifice for our sins. Thank You for the Holy Spirit, who bore witness to His righteousness and continues to guide us. We praise You for the angels who witnessed His glory, for the spread of the gospel to the Gentiles, and for the belief that has spread throughout the world. Help us to live lives that reflect the godliness we have received, lives of love, grace, and obedience. May we always remember the depth of Your love and the price You paid for our salvation. Grant us wisdom and understanding as we meditate on Your Word. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-27.versiculo: John 1:14 KJV: "And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us, (and we beheld his glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father,) full of grace and truth."
2027-01-27.reflexion: John 1:14 is a cornerstone of Christian theology, declaring the incarnation of God. The Word, which was with God and was God (John 1:1), became flesh, dwelling among humanity. This is the pivotal moment where the divine entered the human realm. The phrase, "dwelt among us," is rich with meaning. It speaks not just of a fleeting visit, but of a permanent residence, an intimate connection. God, in the person of Jesus Christ, lived amongst us, experiencing our joys and sorrows, our temptations and triumphs.  The text then highlights the glory of Jesus, seen by those who witnessed His life. This glory is described as the glory of the "only begotten of the Father," emphasizing Jesus' unique relationship with God. Finally, the verse states that Jesus was "full of grace and truth." This signifies that in Him, God’s unmerited favor and absolute truth are fully revealed. This verse provides the foundation for understanding the nature of Jesus and the depth of God's love for humanity. It reminds us of the radical humility of God, who did not remain distant, but chose to become one of us, to redeem and reconcile us to Himself.

para_meditar.texto: But made himself of no reputation, and took upon him the form of a servant, and was made in the likeness of men.
For we have not an high priest which cannot be touched with the feeling of our infirmities; but was in all points tempted like as we are, yet without sin.
And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us, (and we beheld his glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father,) full of grace and truth.

2027-01-27.oracion: Heavenly Father, we are in awe of Your love and mercy, demonstrated through the incarnation of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Thank You for the Word made flesh, who chose to dwell among us, experiencing our humanity. We are grateful for His grace and truth, which He revealed to us. Help us to see the glory of Jesus in our daily lives, to recognize His presence, and to be filled with His grace and truth. Grant us the wisdom to understand the depth of Your sacrifice, and the courage to live in accordance with Your will. Guide us to share the good news with others so they may experience Your love. Strengthen us through the Holy Spirit to walk in your ways, and to be a reflection of your love and truth to the world. We give you thanks and praise for the gift of Jesus Christ, our Savior, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-28.versiculo: Ephesians 6:12 KJV: "For we wrestle not against flesh and blood, but against principalities, against powers, against the rulers of the darkness of this world, against spiritual wickedness in high places."
2027-01-28.reflexion: Today's verse, Ephesians 6:12, unveils a profound spiritual truth: our battle isn't against human adversaries, but against unseen forces of darkness. The apostle Paul reminds us that the true enemy is not flesh and blood, but spiritual wickedness operating in the unseen realm. This understanding is crucial for our spiritual warfare. We often misdirect our efforts, focusing on conflicts with people instead of recognizing the spiritual roots of these struggles. The principalities, powers, and rulers of darkness represent organized, malevolent forces seeking to undermine God's kingdom and our walk with Him. This verse calls us to a heightened awareness of the spiritual dimension. It prompts us to examine our strategies in the face of adversity. Are we relying on human wisdom and strength, or are we arming ourselves with the spiritual armor described in the following verses of Ephesians 6? This battle requires vigilance, prayer, and a deep reliance on the Holy Spirit. It is a call to recognize the true nature of our conflicts and to engage in spiritual warfare with the weapons God has provided, ensuring our victory in Christ.

para_meditar.texto: For the weapons of our warfare are not carnal, but mighty through God to the pulling down of strong holds;
Nay, in all these things we are more than conquerors through him that loved us.
Submit yourselves therefore to God. Resist the devil, and he will flee from you.

2027-01-28.oracion: Heavenly Father, we acknowledge the reality of spiritual warfare and the unseen forces that seek to hinder our walk with You. We confess that we often become entangled in battles against flesh and blood, forgetting the true nature of the conflict. Help us to see beyond the surface and recognize the spiritual forces at play. Grant us discernment to identify the enemy's tactics and the strength to resist them. Equip us with the spiritual armor described in Your Word: the belt of truth, the breastplate of righteousness, the shoes of peace, the shield of faith, the helmet of salvation, and the sword of the Spirit. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, that we may be empowered to stand firm in faith, to pray without ceasing, and to live a life that glorifies You. Give us the courage to confront evil with the truth of Your Word, and the assurance that we are victorious in Christ. We thank You for Your protection and guidance, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-29.versiculo: 1 Thessalonians 5:22 KJV: "Abstain from all appearance of evil."
2027-01-29.reflexion: Today's verse, 1 Thessalonians 5:22, is a clear call to vigilance in our Christian walk: "Abstain from all appearance of evil." This verse challenges us to not only avoid evil acts, but also to distance ourselves from anything that even *looks* like evil. The word "appearance" (or "form" in some translations) implies that we are to shun not just the act itself, but also the potential for it, the temptation, and anything that might lead us down that path. This requires a discerning heart, guided by the Holy Spirit. It means being aware of the influences in our lives – the media we consume, the friendships we cultivate, the places we go – and actively choosing those that build us up in faith and holiness. It’s about proactively protecting our hearts and minds from anything that could compromise our witness for Christ. This is not about legalism or creating a list of arbitrary rules. It's about cultivating a sensitivity to the leading of the Spirit, and a desire to live a life that is blameless and above reproach. It’s about striving to live a life that is not just righteous, but that *appears* righteous to others, so that our actions may glorify God and draw others to Him.

para_meditar.texto: Keep thy heart with all diligence; for out of it are the issues of life.
And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.

Finally, brethren, whatsoever things are true, whatsoever things are honest, whatsoever things are just, whatsoever things are pure, whatsoever things are lovely, whatsoever things are of good report; if there be any virtue, and if there be any praise, think on these things.

2027-01-29.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today, seeking your guidance and wisdom. Help me to be discerning in all areas of my life, and to avoid not only evil deeds, but also the very appearance of evil. Grant me the strength to resist temptation and to flee from anything that might lead me away from you. Renew my mind and fill my heart with a desire to live a life that is pleasing to you. Help me to be sensitive to the Holy Spirit's leading, and to walk in righteousness and truth. Give me the courage to make choices that honor you in all I do, and to be a shining light in a dark world. Empower me to be a good example to others, showing them the love and grace of Jesus Christ. Thank you for your unwavering love and for your constant presence in my life. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-30.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 4:20 KJV: "For the kingdom of God is not in word, but in power."
2027-01-30.reflexion: The Apostle Paul, in 1 Corinthians 4:20, cuts to the heart of true Christianity: "For the kingdom of God is not in word, but in power." This verse challenges us to examine the authenticity of our faith. Are we merely eloquent speakers of the Gospel, or are we demonstrating the transformative power of God in our lives? Paul contrasts mere rhetoric with the undeniable demonstration of God's power. This power is not just about miraculous events, though they may occur, but about the tangible evidence of the Holy Spirit at work: changed lives, acts of love, forgiveness, and the fruit of the Spirit. We are called to live out our faith, not just to proclaim it. Our words should be backed by actions that reflect the character of Christ. Are we known for our pronouncements, or for the genuine impact we have on the lives of others? Do we exhibit patience, kindness, and self-control, even when challenged? The kingdom of God is not a matter of intellectual assent; it's a matter of experiencing and embodying the power of God in every facet of our existence. Let us strive to live lives that are not just spoken, but powerfully lived, demonstrating the reality of God's kingdom to all who observe.

para_meditar.texto: For I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ: for it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth; to the Jew first, and also to the Greek.

But ye shall receive power, after that the Holy Ghost is come upon you: and ye shall be witnesses unto me both in Jerusalem, and in all Judaea, and in Samaria, and unto the uttermost part of the earth.
But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, Meekness, temperance: against such there is no law.

2027-01-30.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today, humbled by the words of 1 Corinthians 4:20. We confess that we often fall short of living a life that truly reflects Your power. Forgive us for the times we have prioritized words over actions, and for the moments when we have failed to exhibit the love, joy, and peace that are the fruit of Your Spirit. Grant us a renewed desire to live a life that is not just spoken, but powerfully lived, demonstrating Your kingdom to all who observe. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, that we may be empowered to be witnesses of Your grace and truth. Help us to be bold in our actions, compassionate in our hearts, and unwavering in our faith. Guide us to be a light in the darkness, shining brightly for Your glory, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-01-31.versiculo: Revelation 1:7 KJV: "Behold, he cometh with clouds; and every eye shall see him, and they also which pierced him: and all kindreds of the earth shall wail because of him. Even so, Amen."
2027-01-31.reflexion:
Today's verse from Revelation paints a vivid picture of the return of Jesus Christ. It speaks of His grand arrival, accompanied by clouds, visible to every eye. This is not a secret coming; it is a public display of His glory. The verse specifically mentions those who pierced Him, acknowledging the historical reality of His crucifixion. The consequence of His return is not only glorious but also sobering. All kindreds of the earth shall wail because of Him. This suggests a time of judgment and reckoning. 

This passage should stir within us both hope and reverence. We are reminded that Jesus will return to claim His rightful place and to judge the earth. It is a call to live with anticipation and faithfulness. Are we ready to meet Him? Are we living lives that reflect His love and grace? This verse is a powerful reminder of the ultimate triumph of good over evil, of the fulfillment of God's promises, and the need for us to remain vigilant in our faith, ready for His return. Let us examine our hearts, ensuring we are found worthy when He appears.

para_meditar.texto: And then shall appear the sign of the Son of man in heaven: and then shall all the tribes of the earth mourn, and they shall see the Son of man coming in the clouds of heaven with power and great glory.

For the Lord himself shall descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of the archangel, and with the trump of God: and the dead in Christ shall rise first: Then we which are alive and remain shall be caught up together with them in the clouds, to meet the Lord in the air: and so shall we ever be with the Lord.
And again another scripture saith, They shall look on him whom they pierced.

2027-01-31.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the promise of Jesus' return. We are filled with hope and anticipation as we contemplate the glorious day when He will come again. Help us to live in the light of His return, always striving to be faithful and obedient to Your will. Grant us the wisdom to understand the importance of this promise and the courage to share it with others. Guide us to examine our hearts and to be ready to meet Him with joy and confidence. We pray for those who have not yet accepted Jesus as their Savior, that they may recognize their need for Him and turn to Him before it is too late. May we be steadfast in our faith and ready to embrace the eternal life He offers. Prepare our hearts, minds, and spirits to be worthy of His presence, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-02-01.versiculo: Acts 10:34-35 KJV: "Then Peter opened his mouth, and said, Of a truth I perceive that God is no respecter of persons: But in every nation he that feareth him, and worketh righteousness, is accepted with him."
2027-02-01.reflexion: Today's passage from Acts 10:34-35 offers a powerful and timeless truth: God is not a respecter of persons. Peter, enlightened by the Holy Spirit, declares this profound understanding after witnessing the outpouring of the Spirit upon the Gentiles. This revelation shattered the long-held prejudices of the Jewish community, who often believed that salvation was exclusively for them. Peter recognizes that God's grace extends to all who fear Him and do what is right, regardless of their background, ethnicity, or social standing. This verse challenges us to examine our own hearts and biases. Are we, like the early disciples, prone to limiting God's love and acceptance to a certain group?
