para_meditar.texto: In my Father's house are many mansions: if it were not so, I would have told you. I go to prepare a place for you. And if I go and prepare a place for you, I will come again, and receive you unto myself; that where I am, there ye may be also.
For I reckon that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which shall be revealed in us.
To an inheritance incorruptible, and undefiled, and that fadeth not away, reserved in heaven for you,

2027-05-10.oracion: Heavenly Father, we give you thanks for the promise of eternal life and the assurance of a heavenly home. We are grateful for the gift of salvation through Jesus Christ, and we acknowledge that our earthly existence is temporary. Help us to live with a focus on the eternal, to treasure the things that truly matter, and to strive to live in a way that reflects your love and grace. Grant us the strength to endure the trials of this life and to keep our eyes fixed on the glory that awaits us. Fill us with hope and faith, and guide us on the path that leads to you. We pray for a deeper understanding of your promises and a greater appreciation for the blessings you have bestowed upon us. We commit our lives to your service, trusting in your unwavering love and care. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-11.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 7:31 KJV: "And they that use this world, as not abusing it: for the fashion of this world passeth away."
2027-05-11.reflexion: Today's verse, 1 Corinthians 7:31, speaks to our relationship with the world and its fleeting nature. Paul encourages us to live in the world, but not to be consumed by it. He uses the analogy of those who use the world, to not abuse it. This is a call to detachment, a reminder that the things of this world – its pleasures, possessions, and pursuits – are temporary. The 'fashion of this world passeth away'. This phrase is a powerful statement about the transience of earthly things. Fashions change, trends fade, and even the most enduring empires crumble. To 'abuse' the world, then, is to make it our ultimate goal, to build our lives and identities around the things that will inevitably disappear. Instead, we are called to live with a sense of perspective, understanding that our true home and treasure are in eternity. We are to use the world, enjoying its blessings and fulfilling our responsibilities, but always with a heart that is set on things above. This requires a conscious effort to resist the allure of materialism, the pursuit of fleeting pleasures, and the anxieties of worldly concerns. It calls for a focus on eternal values: faith, hope, love, and the pursuit of righteousness. Let us strive to live in this world with a spirit of gratitude and detachment, always remembering that we are pilgrims passing through, and our true citizenship is in heaven.

para_meditar.texto: Set your affection on things above, not on things on the earth.

Lay not up for yourselves treasures upon earth, where moth and rust doth corrupt, and where thieves break through and steal: But lay up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where neither moth nor rust doth corrupt, and where thieves do not break through nor steal:
For the love of money is the root of all evil: which while some coveted after, they have erred from the faith, and pierced themselves through with many sorrows.

2027-05-11.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the blessings of this life. Help me to live in this world with a spirit of gratitude and detachment. Protect me from the temptation to be consumed by earthly pursuits and possessions. Grant me wisdom to discern what is truly valuable and to focus my heart on eternal things. Help me to use the world's resources responsibly and to share them with those in need. Fill me with a longing for your presence and a desire to live a life that pleases you. Give me the strength to resist the fleeting pleasures of this world and to seek after the treasures of heaven. Remind me daily that I am a sojourner on this earth, and my true home is with you. Guide me, Lord, in all my ways, and help me to live a life that honors you, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-12.versiculo: Acts 2:21 KJV: "And it shall come to pass, that whosoever shall call on the name of the Lord shall be saved."
2027-05-12.reflexion: Today's verse, Acts 2:21, is a powerful declaration of salvation. It's a simple yet profound truth: if we call upon the name of the Lord, we shall be saved. This verse is rooted in the prophecy of Joel, fulfilled on the day of Pentecost. Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit, preached to the multitude, proclaiming the good news of Jesus Christ. He emphasized that salvation is not earned through works, but received through faith and calling upon the name of the Lord. The "name of the Lord" encompasses the character, authority, and saving power of Jesus. To call on the Lord is more than a mere verbal prayer; it's a heartfelt plea, a recognition of our need for Him, and a surrender to His Lordship. It requires faith, repentance, and a willingness to follow Him. This verse offers hope to all, regardless of their background or past. It is an invitation to experience the transformative power of God's grace and to find eternal life. Let us embrace this promise, turning to the Lord with all our hearts, and experiencing the salvation He so freely offers.

para_meditar.texto: For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved.
For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.

Wherefore God also hath highly exalted him, and given him a name which is above every name: That at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of things in heaven, and things in earth, and things under the earth; And that every tongue should confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father.

2027-05-12.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the incredible promise of salvation found in Your Word. Thank you for sending Your Son, Jesus, to die for our sins, so that we may be saved. We acknowledge our need for You and confess our dependence on Your grace. Help us to call upon Your name with sincere hearts, filled with faith and a desire to follow You. Guide us in our daily lives to live in a way that honors You, reflecting Your love and grace to others. Empower us to share the good news of salvation with those around us, so that they too may experience the joy and peace that comes from knowing You. We pray for strength, wisdom, and discernment as we walk in Your ways. May we always remember the sacrifice of Jesus, and live a life worthy of the calling we have received. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-13.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 6:19 KJV: "What? know ye not that your body is the temple of the Holy Ghost which is in you, which ye have of God, and ye are not your own?"
2027-05-13.reflexion: The Apostle Paul, in 1 Corinthians 6:19, delivers a powerful truth: our bodies are temples of the Holy Spirit. This verse is a call to reverence and responsibility. We are not our own; we have been bought with a price, the ultimate sacrifice of Jesus Christ. This understanding should transform how we live. It compels us to consider the implications of our actions, thoughts, and words. If our bodies house the very Spirit of God, then every choice we make impacts His presence within us. This isn't merely about avoiding outward sin; it's about cultivating a life that honors and reflects the holiness of God. It is a call to stewardship, a recognition that we are entrusted with a sacred vessel. We must be mindful of what we consume, how we treat our bodies, and the company we keep. Our bodies are not disposable; they are a dwelling place for the divine. This realization should lead us to a life of greater discipline, purity, and devotion, constantly striving to be worthy of the Holy Spirit's presence.

para_meditar.texto: I beseech you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is your reasonable service.
Beloved, I wish above all things that thou mayest prosper and be in health, even as thy soul prospereth.

Finally, brethren, whatsoever things are true, whatsoever things are honest, whatsoever things are just, whatsoever things are pure, whatsoever things are lovely, whatsoever things are of good report; if there be any virtue, and if there be any praise, think on these things.

2027-05-13.oracion: Heavenly Father, I thank You for the precious gift of my body, which You have made a temple of the Holy Spirit. Help me to understand the profound responsibility that comes with this truth. Grant me the wisdom and strength to live a life that honors Your presence within me. Guide me in making choices that reflect Your holiness and purity. Help me to guard my thoughts, actions, and words, that they may be pleasing to You. Help me to be a good steward of the body You have given me, caring for it as a sacred vessel. Fill me with Your Spirit daily, and empower me to live a life that glorifies You in all I do. Thank You for Your grace and love, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-14.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 3:13 KJV: "Every man's work shall be made manifest: for the day shall declare it, because it shall be revealed by fire; and the fire shall try every man's work of what sort it is."
2027-05-14.reflexion: Today's verse from 1 Corinthians 3:13 speaks of the revealing fire that will test every person's work. This isn't just about our actions, but the very nature of our labor, the motives behind it, and the foundation upon which it's built. The 'day' Paul refers to is the Day of Judgment, when all that we have done in this life will be brought into the light. The fire is not a literal flame of punishment, but a metaphorical representation of God's scrutiny, His perfect judgment. It will expose the true worth of our endeavors. Are we building on the foundation of Christ, using gold, silver, and precious stones – representing faith, love, and godly character? Or are we building with wood, hay, and stubble – representing works done for selfish gain, pride, or worldly approval? The fire will consume the latter, leaving us with nothing of lasting value. This verse challenges us to examine our lives. What are we building? What are our priorities? Are we striving to please God in all that we do? Let us build with eternal materials, ensuring our work will endure the test of fire and bring glory to His name.

para_meditar.texto: Lay not up for yourselves treasures upon earth, where moth and rust doth corrupt, and where thieves break through and steal: But lay up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where neither moth nor rust doth corrupt, and where thieves do not break through nor steal.
Be not deceived; God is not mocked: for whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reap.
For we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ; that every one may receive the things done in his body, according to that he hath done, whether it be good or bad.

2027-05-14.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with a humble heart, seeking your guidance and wisdom. Help us to understand the gravity of 1 Corinthians 3:13, and to reflect on the work we are doing in our lives. Grant us the discernment to identify the foundations upon which we build our lives, and to ensure they are rooted in your love, your grace, and the teachings of Jesus Christ. Help us to build with gold, silver, and precious stones, so that our work may endure the test of the fire. Give us strength to resist the temptations of the world and to focus on eternal treasures. Guide our actions, thoughts, and motivations, so that everything we do may bring glory to your name. We ask for your grace and mercy to help us live a life worthy of your calling, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-15.versiculo: Mark 3:35 KJV: "For whosoever shall do the will of God, the same is my brother, and my sister, and mother."
2027-05-15.reflexion: Today's verse, Mark 3:35, offers a profound insight into the true nature of family in the Kingdom of God. Jesus, in declaring that those who do the will of God are His brothers, sisters, and mother, transcends the limitations of earthly kinship. This statement is not merely a metaphorical expression; it is a radical redefinition of what constitutes belonging. It shifts the focus from biological ties to spiritual alignment. The essence of family, in the eyes of Jesus, is not determined by blood or lineage, but by obedience and devotion to God's will. This challenges us to examine our priorities. Are we more concerned with familial bonds based on shared genes or with those forged through shared faith and obedience? This verse calls us to action. It challenges us to actively seek and do God's will, understanding that in doing so, we are becoming part of a family far greater than any we could have imagined. It is a family united not by blood, but by the Spirit. The implications are significant. It means that every act of obedience, every act of love, every act of service, brings us closer to Jesus and to this divine family. It is a call to live a life of purpose, a life guided by the Holy Spirit, and a life that reflects the love and grace of God.

para_meditar.texto: But as many as received him, to them gave he power to become the sons of God, even to them that believe on his name:
For as many as are led by the Spirit of God, they are the sons of God.
For ye are all the children of God by faith in Christ Jesus.

2027-05-15.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the beautiful truth of Mark 3:35. Thank You that family is not defined by blood, but by obedience to Your will. Help me to always seek Your will in every aspect of my life, and to be a faithful servant. Grant me the strength and guidance to live in accordance with Your Word, and to love and serve others as Jesus did. Help me to recognize and cherish those who are my brothers and sisters in Christ, and to build relationships founded on faith and obedience. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, that I may be led by You and truly become a part of Your divine family. Thank You for the gift of belonging and for the promise of eternal life, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-16.versiculo: Luke 20:25 KJV: "And he said unto them, Render therefore unto Caesar the things which be Caesar's, and unto God the things which be God's."
2027-05-16.reflexion: Today's verse from Luke presents a profound and timeless principle: the dual responsibility of Christians to both earthly and heavenly authorities. Jesus' response to the Pharisees, who sought to trap him, is a masterclass in wisdom. He acknowledges the legitimacy of civil governance by instructing them to pay taxes to Caesar, recognizing the role of the state in maintaining order and providing services. Simultaneously, he emphasizes the ultimate allegiance to God. This verse calls us to a balanced perspective. We are citizens of two realms: the temporal and the eternal. We must fulfill our duties as citizens, obeying the laws of the land, contributing to society, and showing respect to those in authority. However, our ultimate loyalty belongs to God. We must prioritize His commandments, His will, and His Kingdom. This means living a life of integrity, seeking justice, and loving our neighbors, even when it conflicts with worldly expectations. It is a constant balancing act, a daily examination of our priorities, ensuring that we give to Caesar what is Caesar's and to God what is God's, ultimately striving to live a life pleasing to Him.

para_meditar.texto: Let every soul be subject unto the higher powers. For there is no power but of God: the powers that be are ordained of God.
They say unto him, Caesar's. Then saith he unto them, Render therefore unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's; and unto God the things that are God's.

Submit yourselves to every ordinance of man for the Lord's sake: whether it be to the king, as supreme; Or unto governors, as unto them that are sent by him for the punishment of evildoers, and for the praise of them that do well.

2027-05-16.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the wisdom found in your Word, especially in the teachings of Jesus. We are reminded today of our dual citizenship, belonging both to the earthly realm and to your eternal Kingdom. Help us to be responsible and law-abiding citizens, contributing to the well-being of our communities. Grant us discernment to recognize our responsibilities to those in authority and the wisdom to render to Caesar the things that are Caesar's. Most importantly, Lord, guide us to prioritize our relationship with You. Help us to live a life that honors You in all we do, giving You the glory, the praise, and the devotion that You deserve. Strengthen us to resist the temptations of the world and to walk in your ways, always seeking to do Your will. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, that we might live a life of integrity, justice, and love. We pray all these things, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-17.versiculo: Romans 3:28 KJV: "Therefore we conclude that a man is justified by faith without the deeds of the law."
2027-05-17.reflexion: Today's verse, Romans 3:28, presents a cornerstone of Christian theology: justification by faith. It declares that we are declared righteous in God's eyes, not through our adherence to the Law, but through our faith in Jesus Christ. This is a profound truth that dismantles any notion of earning salvation through good works. The Law, while holy and good, reveals our sinfulness and inability to perfectly obey God. We are all sinners, falling short of God's glory. However, through faith in Jesus, who fulfilled the Law perfectly and paid the penalty for our sins on the cross, we are declared righteous. This righteousness isn't something we achieve; it's a gift, freely given by God's grace. This understanding liberates us from the burden of striving to earn our salvation and instead invites us into a relationship with God based on trust and love. It's a call to embrace the transformative power of faith, recognizing that our good works are a result of our salvation, not a cause of it. Let us live in the freedom of this truth, walking in obedience and gratitude for the grace we have received.

para_meditar.texto: Knowing that a man is not justified by the works of the law, but by the faith of Jesus Christ, even we have believed in Jesus Christ, that we might be justified by the faith of Christ, and not by the works of the law: for by the works of the law shall no flesh be justified.
For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast.
Not by works of righteousness which we have done, but according to his mercy he saved us, by the washing of regeneration, and renewing of the Holy Ghost;

2027-05-17.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the incredible gift of salvation through faith in Jesus Christ. Thank You for declaring us righteous, not because of anything we have done, but because of Your boundless grace and love. Help us to embrace this truth wholeheartedly and to live each day in the freedom that comes from knowing we are forgiven and loved. Grant us a deeper understanding of the transformative power of faith and empower us to walk in obedience, not out of obligation, but out of gratitude. Help us to reflect Your love and grace to others, that they too may come to know the joy of salvation. Guide us to live lives that are pleasing to You, overflowing with the fruits of the Spirit. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, that we may live a life worthy of the calling we have received. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-18.versiculo: James 5:16 KJV: "Confess your faults one to another, and pray one for another, that ye may be healed. The effectual fervent prayer of a righteous man availeth much."
2027-05-18.reflexion: Today's passage from James 5:16 offers a profound call to community and faith. It encourages us to confess our faults to each other, a vital step in fostering genuine relationships and seeking healing. This confession is not merely a social nicety, but a spiritual practice that breaks down walls of pride and isolation. By admitting our shortcomings, we open ourselves to the grace of God and the support of our fellow believers. The verse also highlights the power of prayer, particularly the fervent prayers of the righteous. This doesn't mean those who are perfect, but those who are striving to live righteously, in accordance with God's will. Their prayers, offered with sincerity and passion, are described as 'effectual' and 'availeth much.' This underscores the importance of persistent, heartfelt communication with God. We are called to pray not just for ourselves, but for each other, creating a network of support and intercession. This passage reminds us that we are not meant to walk alone on our faith journey. We are to be in community, vulnerable, and prayerful, trusting in God's power to heal and transform us.

para_meditar.texto: Commit thy works unto the Lord, and thy thoughts shall be established.
If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness.
But thou, when thou prayest, enter into thy closet, and when thou hast shut thy door, pray to thy Father which is in secret; and thy Father which seeth in secret shall reward thee openly.

2027-05-18.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with hearts open to confession and prayer. We acknowledge our shortcomings and ask for your forgiveness and guidance. Help us to cultivate a spirit of humility and vulnerability within our communities, that we may confess our faults to one another and bear each other's burdens. Grant us the wisdom to pray fervently for one another, believing in the power of your healing touch. Fill our hearts with passion for prayer, that we may approach your throne with sincerity and faith. Strengthen our resolve to live righteously, seeking to follow your will in all things. May your grace abound in our lives and the lives of those we pray for. We ask all this, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-19.versiculo: Ephesians 5:16 KJV: "Redeeming the time, because the days are evil."
2027-05-19.reflexion: Ephesians 5:16 is a potent reminder of the preciousness of time and the challenges of the world. Paul urges us to 'redeem the time,' which implies a conscious effort to make the most of every opportunity. The word 'redeeming' suggests buying back, as if time is being stolen from us. In a world filled with distractions, temptations, and evil, our time can easily be squandered on pursuits that lack eternal value. The phrase 'because the days are evil' highlights the urgency. The 'evil' days are not merely bad; they are actively hostile to our spiritual growth. We are called to be vigilant, discerning, and intentional in how we use our time. This verse challenges us to examine our priorities. Are we investing our time in things that align with God's will, or are we allowing the world to dictate our schedule and values? It compels us to be wise stewards of every moment, seeking to use our time for good, for the glory of God, and for the benefit of others. This includes pursuing spiritual disciplines like prayer, studying scripture, and fellowship, as well as living a life of service and love. Let us strive to 'redeem the time' each day, recognizing the brevity of life and the eternal implications of our choices.

para_meditar.texto: So teach us to number our days, that we may apply our hearts unto wisdom.
Walk in wisdom toward them that are without, redeeming the time.
But this I say, brethren, the time is short: it remaineth, that both they that have wives be as though they had none;

2027-05-19.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the gift of time. Forgive us for the times we have wasted it on things that do not honor You. Help us to be mindful of the evil days and the constant battle against distractions. Grant us wisdom and discernment to recognize the opportunities You place before us. Guide us to prioritize the things that matter most: Your Word, prayer, fellowship, and service to others. Give us a renewed sense of purpose and a desire to redeem every moment for Your glory. Empower us to be faithful stewards of our time, making the most of each day to grow closer to You and to impact the world for Your kingdom. Help us to live lives that reflect Your love and grace, spreading the good news of Jesus Christ to all we encounter. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-20.versiculo: John 3:17 KJV: "For God sent not his Son into the world to condemn the world; but that the world through him might be saved."
2027-05-20.reflexion: Today's verse, John 3:17, offers a profound insight into the heart of God. It reveals a God whose primary intent is not judgment, but salvation. The passage declares that God did not send His Son, Jesus, into the world to condemn it. This is a powerful statement, as it underscores the overwhelming love and mercy of God. Instead, Jesus came so that the world might be saved through Him. This highlights the core of the Gospel message: God's desire to redeem and restore humanity to Himself. The verse speaks volumes about the character of God, emphasizing grace over judgment. It shows that God actively seeks to rescue us from the consequences of our sin, offering us a path to eternal life through faith in Jesus Christ. This is a message of hope, a beacon of light in a world often shrouded in darkness. It challenges us to reflect on our own attitudes and motivations. Are we quick to condemn, or do we extend grace and compassion as God has shown us? This verse calls us to embrace the same loving purpose that drove Jesus, to be instruments of salvation in the world, sharing the good news of His saving grace and inviting others to experience the transformative power of His love.

para_meditar.texto: But God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.
Who will have all men to be saved, and to come unto the knowledge of the truth.
The next day John seeth Jesus coming unto him, and saith, Behold the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world.

2027-05-20.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the immeasurable love you have for us, a love that sent your Son, Jesus Christ, to save us from our sins. We are grateful that you do not desire our condemnation, but instead, yearn for our salvation. Help us to understand the depth of your grace and mercy. Open our hearts to receive your love and to extend that same love to others. Give us the strength to share the good news of Jesus Christ with those around us, that they too may experience the joy of your salvation. Guide us to reflect your character, not judging others but offering compassion and understanding. Fill us with the Holy Spirit so that we may be instruments of your peace and love in this world. We pray all these things in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-21.versiculo: James 3:2 KJV: "For in many things we offend all. If any man offend not in word, the same is a perfect man, and able also to bridle the whole body."
2027-05-21.reflexion: Today's verse from James highlights the profound impact of our words. It acknowledges the reality that we all stumble in many ways, but specifically singles out the tongue as a powerful force for good or evil. James asserts that if a person can control their speech, they are a "perfect man," capable of controlling their entire being. This isn't perfection in the sense of sinlessness, but rather, a maturity and self-control that reflects a transformed heart. The tongue, like a rudder, guides the direction of our lives. Uncontrolled, it can steer us toward chaos and destruction. Controlled by the Holy Spirit, it can lead us to peace, wisdom, and the building up of others. This verse challenges us to be mindful of our words, to consider their impact, and to pray for the grace to speak truth, love, and encouragement. It's a call to cultivate a disciplined tongue, reflecting the character of Christ in all that we say.

para_meditar.texto: In the multitude of words there wanteth not sin: but he that refraineth his lips is wise.
Let no corrupt communication proceed out of your mouth, but that which is good to the use of edifying, that it may minister grace unto the hearers.
But I say unto you, That every idle word that men shall speak, they shall give account thereof in the day of judgment.

2027-05-21.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today seeking your guidance and wisdom. I confess that I often struggle with my words, and I am prone to stumble with my tongue. Forgive me for the times I have spoken harshly, carelessly, or in ways that have hurt others. I pray for your Holy Spirit to fill me and to help me control my speech. Grant me the ability to speak words that are edifying, encouraging, and filled with truth and love. Help me to be mindful of the impact of my words and to use them to build up, not to tear down. Give me the strength to bridle my tongue and to reflect the character of Christ in all that I say and do. Guide my words and my heart, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-22.versiculo: Luke 9:24 KJV: "For whosoever will save his life shall lose it: but whosoever will lose his life for my sake, the same shall save it."
2027-05-22.reflexion: This powerful verse from Luke 9:24 speaks to the paradoxical nature of discipleship. Jesus challenges us to consider what we truly value. The natural inclination is to cling to life, to protect our own interests and safety. However, Christ reveals that this very desire, if pursued at the expense of following Him, leads to ultimate loss. The 'life' we desperately try to save here is the one focused on worldly pursuits, comfort, and self-preservation. It's the life that prioritizes our reputation, wealth, and physical well-being above all else. Losing this life, on the other hand, means denying ourselves, taking up our cross, and following Jesus, as mentioned in the preceding verses. It means prioritizing His kingdom, His will, and His teachings. It means being willing to sacrifice our comfort, our desires, and even our lives for the sake of the Gospel. The promise is that those who lose their life for Christ's sake will actually find it – they will discover true life, eternal life, a life filled with purpose, joy, and the abundant blessings of God. This isn't just a future reward; it's a present reality, a transformation that begins the moment we choose to prioritize Christ.

para_meditar.texto: For whosoever will save his life shall lose it: and whosoever will lose his life for my sake shall find it.
For whosoever shall save his life shall lose it; but whosoever shall lose his life for my sake and the gospel's, the same shall save it.

But what things were gain to me, those I counted loss for Christ. Yea doubtless, and I count all things but loss for the excellency of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord: for whom I have suffered the loss of all things, and do count them but dung, that I may win Christ,

2027-05-22.oracion: Lord, help me to understand the profound truth of Luke 9:24. Open my eyes to see the fleeting nature of the things of this world and the eternal value of the kingdom of God. Grant me the courage to lay down my life – my ambitions, my comfort, my self-interest – for Your sake. Help me to embrace the cross, to deny myself, and to follow You wholeheartedly, even when it is difficult. Give me a heart that longs to know You more deeply, to serve You more faithfully, and to love You more completely. Remove the fear of losing my life and fill me with the joy of finding true life in You. Empower me to live a life worthy of the Gospel, one that reflects Your love and grace to all those around me. Guide me to prioritize Your will above all else, and to seek Your kingdom first. I surrender my life to You, Lord, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-23.versiculo: 1 Thessalonians 5:11 KJV: "Wherefore comfort yourselves together, and edify one another, even as also ye do."
2027-05-23.reflexion: Today's verse, 1 Thessalonians 5:11, is a simple yet powerful command: "Wherefore comfort yourselves together, and edify one another." It speaks to the very heart of Christian community and the essential role we play in each other's spiritual well-being. The word "comfort" here implies more than just a fleeting sense of ease; it speaks to the deep, abiding peace and solace that comes from shared faith and mutual support. It's about being present for one another in times of difficulty, offering words of encouragement, and sharing the burdens of life. "Edify" means to build up, to strengthen, to encourage growth. This isn't about empty praise, but about speaking truth in love, challenging one another to live lives worthy of the Gospel, and pointing each other towards Christ. The verse reminds us that we are not meant to journey through life alone. We are part of the Body of Christ, and as members of that body, we are called to actively participate in the well-being of others. It is a call to action, urging us to be intentional in our relationships, to be a source of comfort and encouragement, and to actively build up the faith of those around us. This is not just a suggestion; it is a call to action, a fundamental part of our calling as believers.

para_meditar.texto: Be kindly affectioned one to another with brotherly love; in honour preferring one another.
Bear ye one another's burdens, and so fulfil the law of Christ.

And let us consider one another to provoke unto love and to good works: Not forsaking the assembling of ourselves together, as the manner of some is; but exhorting one another: and so much the more, as ye see the day approaching.

2027-05-23.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the gift of community and the call to love and support one another. We acknowledge our need for comfort and encouragement, and we are grateful for the opportunity to offer these to others. Help us to be mindful of the needs of those around us, and to be a source of strength and encouragement. Grant us the wisdom to speak words of truth in love, and to build up the faith of those in our lives. Give us hearts that are compassionate and willing to share the burdens of others. Help us to be a reflection of Your love and grace in all that we do. May we be instruments of Your peace, comfort, and encouragement, building each other up in faith and love. We ask all this in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-24.versiculo: Luke 19:10 KJV: "For the Son of man is come to seek and to save that which was lost."
2027-05-24.reflexion: Today's verse, Luke 19:10, unveils the very heart of God's mission: to seek and save the lost. This powerful declaration, spoken by Jesus, encapsulates the entirety of His earthly ministry. It paints a vivid picture of a loving Shepherd relentlessly pursuing the one lost sheep, a gracious Physician tending to the sick, and a merciful Savior extending a hand to the broken. The 'lost' are not just those who have strayed geographically, but those spiritually adrift, separated from God. This verse underscores the active role of Jesus. He did not simply wait for humanity to find Him; He came, He sought, and He continues to seek. The 'saving' aspect signifies not just rescue from eternal damnation, but also restoration of relationship with God, and the promise of a life abundant in grace, forgiveness, and purpose. This verse challenges us to examine our own lives. Are we actively participating in this divine mission? Are we seeking out those who are lost, sharing the good news, and pointing them towards the saving grace of Jesus Christ? The call to action is clear: to be co-workers with Christ, actively involved in seeking and saving the lost, demonstrating His love in word and deed.

para_meditar.texto: For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.
For the Son of man is come to save that which was lost.

I will seek that which was lost, and bring again that which was driven away, and will bind up that which was broken, and will strengthen that which was sick: but I will destroy the fat and the strong; I will feed them with judgment.

2027-05-24.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank You for sending Your Son, Jesus, to seek and save us, the lost. We are eternally grateful for His sacrifice and the incredible gift of salvation. Lord, open our hearts to the needs of those around us who are lost and searching. Give us the courage and wisdom to share the good news of Your love and grace with them. Help us to be Your hands and feet, actively participating in Your mission to bring people into a relationship with You. Empower us to demonstrate Your love in every aspect of our lives, so that others may see You in us. Fill us with Your compassion and guide us to reach out to the hurting and the broken, offering them the hope and healing that only You can provide. Grant us a heart for the lost and a passion to share the Gospel. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-25.versiculo: 2 Thessalonians 3:16 KJV: "Now the Lord of peace himself give you peace always by all means. The Lord be with you all."
2027-05-25.reflexion: Today's verse, 2 Thessalonians 3:16, offers a powerful benediction, a profound wish for peace from the Lord Himself. The Apostle Paul, concluding his letter, doesn't just offer a generic farewell; he invokes the 'Lord of peace' to bestow this precious gift upon the Thessalonians. The repetition of 'peace' emphasizes its importance, and the phrase 'always by all means' suggests a comprehensive and enduring peace that transcends circumstances. This peace isn't merely the absence of conflict; it's a deep, abiding tranquility that comes from a relationship with God. It’s the inner calm that allows us to navigate the storms of life with faith and confidence. We are reminded that true peace is not found in external factors, but in the Lord. It is a peace that surpasses all understanding, guarding our hearts and minds in Christ Jesus. The second part of the verse, 'The Lord be with you all,' reinforces the intimacy of this blessing. It is a declaration of God's presence and protection, a constant assurance that we are not alone. As we go about our day, let us embrace the peace offered by the Lord, allowing it to permeate our thoughts, words, and actions, and remember His constant presence with us, providing comfort, strength, and guidance in every situation.

para_meditar.texto: And the peace of God, which passeth all understanding, shall keep your hearts and minds through Christ Jesus.
Peace I leave with you, my peace I give unto you: not as the world giveth, give I unto you. Let not your heart be troubled, neither let it be afraid.
Now the God of peace be with you all. Amen.

2027-05-25.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the gift of peace that surpasses all understanding. I thank You for the promise of Your presence, that You are always with me. Lord, I pray for the peace that comes from knowing You, a peace that guards my heart and mind in Christ Jesus. Help me to embrace this peace in all areas of my life, allowing it to guide my thoughts, words, and actions. Remove any anxiety or fear that might cloud my mind, and replace it with Your unwavering peace. Grant me the strength to navigate the challenges of life with faith and trust in Your love. May I always be mindful of Your presence, and may Your peace be upon me and upon all those I encounter today. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-26.versiculo: Philippians 2:5 KJV: "Let this mind be in you, which was also in Christ Jesus:"
2027-05-26.reflexion: Philippians 2:5 calls us to adopt the very mind of Christ Jesus. This is not merely an intellectual exercise; it is a profound transformation of our inner being. It speaks of humility, selflessness, and a willingness to prioritize the needs of others above our own. Jesus, though He was in the form of God, did not consider equality with God something to be grasped. Instead, He emptied Himself, taking on the form of a servant, and humbled Himself to the point of death, even death on a cross. This verse challenges us to examine our own hearts and minds. Are we striving to embody this same spirit of humility and self-sacrifice? Are we willing to relinquish our own desires and preferences for the sake of serving others and glorifying God? The call to have the mind of Christ is a call to a life of obedience, love, and unwavering faith. It's a daily commitment to emulate the character and actions of our Savior, allowing His mind to shape our thoughts, words, and deeds. This verse is not a suggestion; it is a command, a call to a radical transformation that defines the Christian life.

para_meditar.texto: And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.
Take my yoke upon you, and learn of me; for I am meek and lowly in heart: and ye shall find rest unto your souls.
For even hereunto were ye called: because Christ also suffered for us, leaving us an example, that ye should follow his steps:

2027-05-26.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before You today, seeking Your guidance and grace. I pray that You will help me to cultivate the mind of Christ within me. Grant me the humility to put others' needs before my own, and the selflessness to serve them with a genuine heart. Remove from me any selfishness, pride, or resentment that may hinder me from embodying Your Son's character. Open my eyes to see the world through His perspective, and empower me to act in accordance with His teachings. Give me the strength to resist temptation and to live a life that glorifies You. Fill me with Your love, Your compassion, and Your unwavering faith. Help me to be a vessel of Your grace and mercy to all those I encounter. Guide my thoughts, words, and actions so that they may reflect the very mind of Christ. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-27.versiculo: John 6:40 KJV: "And this is the will of him that sent me, that every one which seeth the Son, and believeth on him, may have everlasting life: and I will raise him up at the last day."
2027-05-27.reflexion: John 6:40 offers a powerful promise and a clear path to eternal life. Jesus declares that the Father's will is for all who see the Son—recognize Him for who He is—and believe in Him, to have everlasting life. This verse highlights the central importance of faith. It's not enough to merely acknowledge Jesus; we must actively believe in Him, embracing His teachings and accepting His sacrifice. The reward is not just a vague hope, but the assurance of everlasting life, a promise of resurrection on the last day. This reveals the Father's deep love and desire for humanity's salvation. The verse challenges us to examine our own faith. Do we truly see Jesus? Do we believe in Him with our whole hearts? This is not a passive acceptance, but an active commitment, a daily walk in faith. The promise is a testament to God's grace and His unwavering desire for us to spend eternity with Him. It is a call to action, urging us to embrace the gift of everlasting life through faith in Jesus Christ.

para_meditar.texto: That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved.
But without faith it is impossible to please him: for he that cometh to God must believe that he is, and that he is a rewarder of them that diligently seek him.
These things have I written unto you that believe on the name of the Son of God; that ye may know that ye have eternal life, and that ye may believe on the name of the Son of God.

2027-05-27.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the promise of everlasting life through faith in your Son, Jesus Christ. Help me to see Jesus clearly, to recognize Him as my Lord and Savior. Grant me the strength to believe in Him with my whole heart, to embrace His teachings, and to live a life that reflects my faith. Strengthen my belief and help me to share this good news with others, so they too may experience the joy of eternal life. Guide me daily in my walk with You, and fill me with the peace that surpasses all understanding. Help me to trust in Your will and to live in accordance with Your word. Thank you for Your unwavering love and grace, which makes this promise possible. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-28.versiculo: 1 Peter 2:2 KJV: "As newborn babes, desire the sincere milk of the word, that ye may grow thereby:"
2027-05-28.reflexion:
Today's verse, 1 Peter 2:2, calls us to a fundamental aspect of Christian life: a yearning for the pure milk of the Word. Peter uses the powerful analogy of newborn babes, illustrating our spiritual need for nourishment. Just as a baby craves milk for physical sustenance, we are to crave the Word of God for spiritual growth. This 'sincere milk' is pure, untainted by human opinion or worldly distractions. It is the unadulterated truth found in scripture, the very words of God. 

This verse challenges us to examine our own appetites. Are we truly hungry for the Word? Do we approach the Bible with a genuine desire to learn, understand, and apply its teachings to our lives? Or have we become complacent, satisfied with superficial knowledge or neglecting consistent engagement with scripture? The promise is clear: we will grow. Spiritual maturity is not a passive process; it requires active participation, a conscious decision to seek out and consume the life-giving milk of the Word. This means dedicating time to read, study, and meditate on the Bible, allowing its truths to transform our minds and shape our hearts. Let us, therefore, cultivate a sincere desire, a deep longing for the Word, that we may grow into the fullness of Christ.

para_meditar.texto: Thy word is a lamp unto my feet, and a light unto my path.

For the word of God is quick, and powerful, and sharper than any twoedged sword, piercing even to the dividing asunder of soul and spirit, and of the joints and marrow, and is a discerner of the thoughts and intents of the heart.
But he answered and said, It is written, Man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that proceedeth out of the mouth of God.

2027-05-28.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with hearts that long for your Word. We acknowledge our dependence on your truth, just as a newborn babe depends on milk for nourishment. Help us to cultivate a sincere desire for the Scriptures, to approach them with a hunger that drives us to seek understanding and wisdom. Open our minds and hearts to receive your life-giving words, that we may grow in faith, knowledge, and obedience. Grant us the discipline to read, study, and meditate on your Word daily, allowing it to transform our lives and shape our character. Fill us with the Holy Spirit, that we may understand the deep things of God. We pray for a renewed passion for your Word in our lives, that we may become more like Christ. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-29.versiculo: 2 Corinthians 8:7 KJV: "Therefore, as ye abound in every thing, in faith, and utterance, and knowledge, and in all diligence, and in your love to us, see that ye abound in this grace also."
2027-05-29.reflexion: Today's verse, 2 Corinthians 8:7, calls us to excel in the grace of giving, mirroring the generosity of the Macedonian churches. Paul acknowledges their abundance in faith, communication, knowledge, diligence, and love. However, he urges them to 'abound in this grace also' – the grace of giving. This isn't a mere suggestion, but a call to action. It's a reminder that spiritual maturity is demonstrated not just through our inner life, but also by our outward expressions of love and compassion. Giving, in this context, isn't just about money; it's about sharing our resources, time, and talents to support the work of God and to meet the needs of others. It requires a deliberate choice, a willingness to surrender what we have, and a recognition that everything we possess ultimately belongs to God. To 'abound' in this grace implies a lifestyle of generosity, a heart that is constantly seeking opportunities to bless others. It's a challenge to evaluate our priorities and to ensure that our giving reflects the abundance of blessings we have received. It's a reminder that true faith manifests itself in tangible acts of love and service. May we strive to emulate the generosity of the early Christians, allowing the grace of giving to overflow from our hearts and into the lives of those around us.

para_meditar.texto: The liberal soul shall be made fat: and he that watereth shall be watered also himself.

Give, and it shall be given unto you; good measure, pressed down, and shaken together, and running over, shall men give into your bosom. For with the same measure that ye mete withal it shall be measured to you again.
That they do good, that they be rich in good works, ready to distribute, willing to communicate;

2027-05-29.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank You for the abundance of Your blessings in our lives. We acknowledge that all we have comes from You, and we are grateful for Your provision. We pray for a generous spirit, a heart that is open and willing to give as You have given to us. Help us to see the needs of others and to respond with compassion and love. Grant us the wisdom to use our resources wisely and to share them joyfully for the advancement of Your kingdom. Give us the strength to overcome any fear or hesitation in giving, and fill us with a desire to abound in the grace of giving, just as You have called us to do. May our actions reflect our faith and bring glory to Your name. Help us to be a blessing to those around us, both in our words and in our deeds, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-30.versiculo: 1 Timothy 1:5 KJV: "Now the end of the commandment is charity out of a pure heart, and of a good conscience, and of faith unfeigned:"
2027-05-30.reflexion: Today's scripture, 1 Timothy 1:5, reveals the core of the Christian life: love flowing from a pure heart, a clear conscience, and genuine faith. Paul emphasizes that the ultimate goal of the law, the 'end of the commandment,' is not mere obedience but a love that originates from within. This love is not superficial or conditional; it is rooted in a pure heart, free from hypocrisy and selfish motives. A 'good conscience' serves as the moral compass, guiding our actions and ensuring that our love is expressed in truth and integrity. Finally, 'faith unfeigned' speaks to the authenticity of our belief. It’s a faith that is genuine, unwavering, and not merely for show. This verse challenges us to examine the source of our actions. Are we motivated by a love that springs from a heart cleansed by God's grace? Do we strive to maintain a clear conscience, sensitive to the leading of the Holy Spirit? And is our faith a true reflection of our inner transformation, or is it merely a performance? Embracing these principles allows us to live a life that honors God and reflects His love to those around us.

para_meditar.texto: Let love be without dissimulation. Abhor that which is evil; cleave to that which is good.
My little children, let us not love in word, neither in tongue; but in deed and in truth.
Let us draw near with a true heart in full assurance of faith, having our hearts sprinkled from an evil conscience, and our bodies washed with pure water.

2027-05-30.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today seeking to align my heart with your will. Help me to cultivate a love that is pure, selfless, and overflowing with grace. Grant me a conscience that is sensitive to Your voice, guiding me in all my actions. Strengthen my faith, Lord, that it may be unfeigned and unwavering, a true reflection of my relationship with You. Help me to live a life that is marked by authenticity and integrity, loving others as You have loved me. Purify my heart, renew my mind, and empower me to walk in the truth of Your word. I pray for the strength to live out the principles of 1 Timothy 1:5 in every aspect of my life, that my actions may bring glory to Your name. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-05-31.versiculo: Romans 4:13 KJV: "For the promise, that he should be the heir of the world, was not to Abraham, or to his seed, through the law, but through the righteousness of faith."
2027-05-31.reflexion: Romans 4:13 unveils a profound truth about the nature of God's covenant with Abraham and, by extension, with us. The promise of inheriting the world wasn't contingent upon Abraham's adherence to the Law, but rather, it was a result of his faith. This verse underscores the foundational principle of justification by faith, a cornerstone of the Christian faith. The world was promised to Abraham not because he earned it through his good deeds, but because he believed God's promise, and God credited his faith as righteousness. This challenges the notion that we can achieve salvation through our own efforts. Instead, it highlights the pivotal role of grace. The Law, while holy and good, could not provide the means for inheriting the promise. It served to reveal sin, not to remove it. This verse is a potent reminder that our inheritance, our eternal life, is a gift received through faith in Jesus Christ. It's a call to abandon self-reliance and embrace the righteousness that comes from God, available to all who believe. It’s a call to recognize that our relationship with God is not based on our performance, but on His faithfulness and our trust in Him.

para_meditar.texto: But the scripture hath concluded all under sin, that the promise by faith of Jesus Christ might be given to them that believe.
Now faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen.
For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast.

2027-05-31.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the promise of inheritance through faith. Thank You that my salvation is not earned but freely given through the righteousness of Jesus Christ. Help me to continually place my trust in You, recognizing that my efforts alone cannot secure my place in Your kingdom. Grant me a heart that is receptive to Your grace and a spirit that is filled with unwavering faith. Strengthen my belief in Your promises and guide me to live a life that reflects my dependence on You. Help me to share this good news with others and proclaim the freedom that comes from believing. May I always remember that it is by faith that I am saved, and not by my own deeds. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-06-01.versiculo: Matthew 11:29 KJV: "Take my yoke upon you, and learn of me; for I am meek and lowly in heart: and ye shall find rest unto your souls."
2027-06-01.reflexion:
The invitation of Jesus in Matthew 11:29 is a call to a life of true rest. He doesn't offer a quick fix or a superficial solution, but a profound transformation of the soul. The yoke He offers is not a burden, but a means of walking alongside Him, learning from His meekness and humility. This is a crucial distinction. The world often promises rest through possessions, power, or pleasure, but these are fleeting and ultimately unsatisfying. Jesus promises rest that comes from a deep, inner peace, a state of being that transcends circumstances. 

To take His yoke means to submit to His teachings and example. It requires us to shed the burdens of pride, self-reliance, and striving, and to embrace humility and dependence on God. It demands a willingness to learn from Jesus, to observe His character, and to imitate His actions. The promise that follows—'ye shall find rest unto your souls'—is not just a promise of physical ease, but of spiritual tranquility. It is the rest that comes from knowing God, from being in His presence, and from living a life aligned with His will. It's a rest born of trust, obedience, and a heart that is truly meek and lowly.

para_meditar.texto: He maketh me to lie down in green pastures: he leadeth me beside the still waters.
Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known unto God.
There remaineth therefore a rest to the people of God.

2027-06-01.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before You today burdened by the cares of this world. I recognize that my striving and self-reliance have only led to exhaustion and unrest. I confess my pride and my unwillingness to surrender to Your will. Lord Jesus, I accept Your invitation. I take Your yoke upon me, and I ask for the grace to learn from You, to walk in Your humility, and to find the rest You promise. Help me to release the burdens I carry and to trust in Your provision and guidance. Fill my soul with Your peace, that I may experience the tranquility that comes from knowing You. Guide me to be meek and lowly in heart, and draw me closer to Your presence every day. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-06-02.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 2:9 KJV: "But as it is written, Eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love him."
2027-06-02.reflexion: Today's verse, 1 Corinthians 2:9, offers a breathtaking glimpse into the boundless grace and unimaginable blessings that await those who love God. Paul, inspired by the Holy Spirit, declares that the wonders God has prepared are beyond human comprehension. Our eyes have not seen, our ears have not heard, and our minds have not conceived the magnitude of God's provision. This passage challenges us to elevate our perspective beyond the limitations of our earthly existence. It encourages us to cultivate a heart of love for God, for it is to those who love Him that these extraordinary blessings are promised. We often get caught up in the trials and tribulations of this world, focusing on what we lack or what we perceive as unfair. However, 1 Corinthians 2:9 reminds us to shift our focus upwards, to set our minds on the eternal rewards that await us. It calls us to trust in God's promises, to believe in the unseen realities of His kingdom, and to live with an unwavering hope in the glorious future He has prepared for His beloved.

para_meditar.texto: For I reckon that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which shall be revealed in us.
And God shall wipe away all tears from their eyes; and there shall be no more death, neither sorrow, nor crying, neither shall there be any more pain: for the former things are passed away.

Finally, brethren, whatsoever things are true, whatsoever things are honest, whatsoever things are just, whatsoever things are pure, whatsoever things are lovely, whatsoever things are of good report; if there be any virtue, and if there be any praise, think on these things.

2027-06-02.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with hearts filled with gratitude and anticipation. Thank you for the promise of 1 Corinthians 2:9, for the assurance that you have prepared wonders beyond our imagination for those who love you. Help us to fix our eyes on the eternal, on the glorious future you have promised us. Grant us the faith to trust in your unseen blessings, to believe in your unwavering love, and to live each day with a heart of devotion and gratitude. Help us to resist the distractions of this world and to focus on the eternal treasures that await us in your presence. Guide us to love you more deeply, to serve you more faithfully, and to share your love with others. May we always be mindful of the blessings that await us, the glories that have been prepared, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-06-03.versiculo: Hebrews 13:5 KJV: "Let your conversation be without covetousness; and be content with such things as ye have: for he hath said, I will never leave thee, nor forsake thee."
2027-06-03.reflexion: Hebrews 13:5 is a powerful declaration of God's unwavering presence and provision. The verse begins with a call to live a life free from the bondage of covetousness, a dangerous desire for more and more, which can lead to discontentment and a separation from God. Instead, we are called to be content with what we have, recognizing that God's provision is sufficient. The heart of the verse is the promise: "I will never leave thee, nor forsake thee." This is not just a statement of future intent, but a reflection of God's character, His faithfulness, and His constant presence with His children. This promise is a source of immense comfort, strength, and hope. It reminds us that we are never truly alone, even in the face of hardship, uncertainty, or fear. God is with us, guiding us, protecting us, and providing for our needs. To live in accordance with this promise is to trust in God's provision, to find our satisfaction in Him, and to live a life of gratitude and contentment, knowing that we lack nothing when we have Him. This verse calls us to a radical dependence on God, a lifestyle of faith that acknowledges His constant presence and provision in every aspect of our lives. It's a call to trust, even when we cannot see the full picture, and to rest in the assurance of His unchanging love.

para_meditar.texto: Not that I speak in respect of want: for I have learned, in whatsoever state I am, therewith to be content.
But seek ye first the kingdom of God, and his righteousness; and all these things shall be added unto you.
The Lord is my shepherd; I shall not want.

2027-06-03.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the powerful promise in Hebrews 13:5. Thank you that you will never leave me nor forsake me. Help me, Lord, to live a life free from covetousness and to be content with what I have, recognizing Your abundant provision in my life. Grant me the wisdom to trust in Your plan, even when I face challenges or uncertainty. Fill my heart with gratitude for Your blessings and help me to always seek Your kingdom first. Give me the strength to rely on You daily, knowing that You are my constant companion and provider. Help me to reflect Your faithfulness in my interactions with others and in all that I do. I ask for Your guidance, protection, and provision throughout my life, trusting in Your unchanging love and grace. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-06-04.versiculo: Matthew 12:20 KJV: "A bruised reed shall he not break, and smoking flax shall he not quench, till he send forth judgment unto victory."
2027-06-04.reflexion: Matthew 12:20 offers a profound glimpse into the character of Jesus and the nature of God's redemptive work. The verse speaks of gentleness and compassion, contrasting sharply with a harsh or judgmental approach. The 'bruised reed' represents the broken and vulnerable, those who are already wounded and struggling. Jesus, rather than crushing them further, offers healing and restoration. The 'smoking flax' symbolizes the flickering embers of faith, the struggling hope that is barely alive. He does not extinguish it, but nurtures it until it bursts into flame. This passage reveals a God who is patient, merciful, and deeply concerned with the well-being of the marginalized and the faint of heart. It encourages us to approach others with the same gentleness and compassion that Jesus displayed. We are called to be restorers, not destroyers, to lift up those who are downcast, and to fan the flames of faith in those who are struggling. This verse challenges us to examine our own hearts and actions, to ensure that we are reflecting the love and grace of God in our interactions with others.

para_meditar.texto: A bruised reed shall he not break, and the smoking flax shall he not quench: he shall bring forth judgment unto truth.
The Lord is nigh unto them that are of a broken heart; and saveth such as be of a contrite spirit.
For we have not an high priest which cannot be touched with the feeling of our infirmities; but was in all points tempted like as we are, yet without sin.

2027-06-04.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for revealing Your heart of compassion and mercy through the words of Jesus. Help us to see others as You see them, with tenderness and understanding. Grant us the grace to be patient with those who are struggling, offering them encouragement and support rather than judgment. Enable us to be restorers of hope and faith, nurturing the flickering flames in the hearts of those who are weary. Guide us to reflect Your love in all that we do, extending grace and mercy to all we encounter. Give us the wisdom to discern when to speak, and when to listen, and always to act with kindness and humility. May we be instruments of Your peace and healing in a broken world, always pointing others to Your unending love and grace. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-06-05.versiculo: Matthew 4:19 KJV: "And he saith unto them, Follow me, and I will make you fishers of men."
2027-06-05.reflexion: The call to discipleship in Matthew 4:19 is a pivotal moment in the Gospel. Jesus, having overcome temptation in the wilderness, immediately begins to gather His followers. He doesn't offer riches, fame, or earthly power; instead, He extends a simple, yet profound invitation: "Follow me." This call is not just a request to physically trail behind Him, but a summons to a life of transformation. The promise that accompanies this invitation is even more compelling: "I will make you fishers of men." This is not just a job description, but a declaration of purpose. Jesus offers to equip them, to transform them from ordinary fishermen into instruments for the salvation of souls. It speaks of a new identity, a new calling, and a new destiny. The fishermen, likely accustomed to the rhythms of the sea, were asked to leave their nets, their livelihood, and their familiar world behind. This required faith, trust, and a willingness to embrace the unknown. Their obedience serves as a powerful example for us today. We, too, are called to follow Jesus, to leave behind the things that hold us back, and to dedicate ourselves to the task of spreading the Gospel. This verse reminds us that our lives, when surrendered to Christ, can be used to bring others into the Kingdom of God. It's a call to action, a call to purpose, and a call to a life that reflects the love and grace of Jesus Christ.

para_meditar.texto: And Jesus said unto them, Come ye after me, and I will make you to become fishers of men.

Ye have not chosen me, but I have chosen you, and ordained you, that ye should go and bring forth fruit, and that your fruit should remain: that whatsoever ye shall ask of the Father in my name, he may give it you.
And the things that thou hast heard of me among many witnesses, the same commit thou to faithful men, who shall be able to teach others also.

2027-06-05.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the clear call to follow You. Thank You for the promise of transformation, that You will make us fishers of men. Help us to be obedient to Your call, to lay down our own desires and embrace Your purpose for our lives. Give us the courage to step out in faith, to share the Gospel with those around us, and to be a light in this dark world. Grant us the wisdom to understand Your teachings and the strength to live them out. Help us to love others as You love us, and to be a witness of Your grace and mercy. Guide us in our words, and actions, and let us bring glory to your name. We pray for opportunities to share the Gospel and for the hearts of those who hear to be receptive. We ask for Your guidance and strength in all that we do, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-06-06.versiculo: Luke 6:27-28 KJV: "But I say unto you which hear, Love your enemies, do good to them which hate you, Bless them that curse you, and pray for them which despitefully use you."
2027-06-06.reflexion: Today's passage from Luke challenges us to a radical love, one that transcends the boundaries of our natural inclinations. Jesus, in his Sermon on the Plain, calls us to love our enemies, to do good to those who hate us, to bless those who curse us, and to pray for those who mistreat us. This is not a suggestion; it's a command, a cornerstone of the Christian faith. It's easy to love those who love us, to be kind to those who are kind to us. But Jesus elevates us to a higher standard, a divine standard. He calls us to mirror God's own love, which extends even to those who are hostile towards Him. This is not about condoning evil; it's about overcoming evil with good. It's about breaking the cycle of hatred and replacing it with the transformative power of love. It requires a conscious effort, a daily decision to choose grace over resentment, forgiveness over retribution. It demands that we see the image of God in every person, even those who may seem most unlikeable. By embracing this radical love, we not only reflect the character of Christ but also pave the way for reconciliation and healing in a broken world. This is not a passive love; it is an active love, demonstrated through our actions, our words, and our prayers. It is a love that seeks the good of others, regardless of their response. It is the ultimate expression of faith and the embodiment of the Gospel.

para_meditar.texto: Bless them which persecute you: bless, and curse not.
But I say unto you, Love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them which despitefully use you, and persecute you;
Not rendering evil for evil, or railing for railing: but contrariwise blessing; knowing that ye are thereunto called, that ye should inherit a blessing.

2027-06-06.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You today, humbled by Your command to love our enemies. It is a challenge that seems impossible in our human strength, yet we know that with You, all things are possible. Grant us the grace to see others through Your eyes, to recognize Your image in every person, even those who wrong us. Help us to overcome the temptation to retaliate, to hold onto bitterness, and to seek revenge. Fill our hearts with Your love, a love that is patient, kind, and forgiving. Guide us to bless those who curse us, to do good to those who hate us, and to pray for those who mistreat us. Give us the strength to choose love, forgiveness, and compassion in every situation, reflecting Your glory to the world. We thank you for the example of Jesus Christ, who loved us even when we were His enemies. Help us to follow in His footsteps, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-06-07.versiculo: Ephesians 3:16 KJV: "That he would grant you, according to the riches of his glory, to be strengthened with might by his Spirit in the inner man;"
2027-06-07.reflexion: Today's verse from Ephesians 3:16 is a powerful prayer for spiritual empowerment. Paul prays for the Ephesians, and by extension, for us, that we might be strengthened with might by God's Spirit in our inner being. This isn't about physical strength or worldly power; it's about inner fortitude, the kind that comes from a deep connection with the Holy Spirit. It’s a request for an infusion of God's power, a power that transcends our natural limitations and enables us to live a life pleasing to Him. The phrase 'according to the riches of his glory' reminds us that God's resources are limitless. He doesn't give sparingly; He gives abundantly, lavishly, and generously. This inner strength is not just for personal comfort, but for the purpose of understanding the vastness of God's love, as Paul goes on to describe in the following verses. It’s a strength that equips us to persevere through trials, resist temptation, and live a life that reflects the glory of God. Let us embrace this prayer and seek to be strengthened in our inner man, drawing upon the boundless resources of God's glory.

para_meditar.texto: I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me.
He giveth power to the faint; and to them that have no might he increaseth strength.
And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to his purpose.

2027-06-07.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today, mindful of my weaknesses and limitations. I pray, as Paul did for the Ephesians, that you would strengthen me with might by your Spirit in my inner man. Grant me the inner fortitude to face the challenges of this life, to resist temptation, and to live a life that honors you. Fill me with your peace and your joy, and help me to understand more fully the depth of your love. Help me to rely on your strength, and not my own. Grant me the wisdom to discern your will and the courage to follow it. I ask that you would work in my heart, transforming me more and more into the image of your Son, Jesus Christ. Empower me to live a life that reflects your glory, and to be a blessing to those around me. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-06-08.versiculo: Matthew 22:21 KJV: "They say unto him, Caesar's. Then saith he unto them, Render therefore unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's; and unto God the things that are God's."
2027-06-08.reflexion: Today's verse, Matthew 22:21, offers a profound teaching on the balance between earthly and spiritual responsibilities. Jesus, faced with a trap question regarding paying taxes to Caesar, cuts through the political and religious complexities with a simple yet powerful statement. He acknowledges the authority of the state by instructing to give to Caesar what is Caesar's. However, He immediately elevates the priority, adding, "and unto God the things that are God's." This is not just a matter of finances; it is a declaration of our dual citizenship. We are citizens of the earthly realm, with duties and obligations, but more importantly, we are citizens of the Kingdom of God. The things that are God's encompass our hearts, our minds, our time, our talents, and our entire lives. This verse challenges us to evaluate our priorities. Are we giving Caesar more than we give to God? Are we so consumed by earthly concerns that we neglect our spiritual growth and our relationship with Him? Let us strive to live a life that honors both realms, remembering that our ultimate allegiance belongs to God, and our ultimate reward is in His eternal kingdom. We must discern what truly belongs to us and what belongs to God.

para_meditar.texto: Let every soul be subject unto the higher powers. For there is no power but of God: the powers that be are ordained of God.
Honour all men. Love the brotherhood. Fear God. Honour the king.
And whatsoever ye do, do it heartily, as to the Lord, and not unto men;

2027-06-08.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank You for the wisdom found in Your Word. Help us to understand the balance between our earthly duties and our spiritual obligations. Guide us to render unto Caesar what is Caesar's, but more importantly, to render unto You all that is Yours: our hearts, our minds, and our lives. Help us to prioritize our relationship with You above all else, seeking Your will in every decision and action. Grant us the discernment to recognize what truly matters in this life, and the strength to live according to Your Word. May we always remember that we are pilgrims on this earth, but citizens of Your eternal Kingdom. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, that we may be a light to the world. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-06-09.versiculo: 2 Timothy 1:12 KJV: "For the which cause I also suffer these things: nevertheless I am not ashamed: for I know whom I have believed, and am persuaded that he is able to keep that which I have committed unto him against that day."
2027-06-09.reflexion: Today's verse, 2 Timothy 1:12, is a powerful declaration of unwavering faith in the face of adversity. Paul, writing from prison, acknowledges his suffering but boldly proclaims that he is not ashamed. This is because he knows the object of his faith – he knows *whom* he has believed. This isn't a vague, general belief; it's a personal relationship with Jesus Christ. He has committed his life, his very soul, to the Lord. Paul is persuaded, absolutely convinced, that God is able to keep what he has entrusted to Him. This commitment isn't a passive one; it's an active and deliberate act of surrender. The 'what' that Paul has committed encompasses his life, his testimony, and his eternal destiny. He trusts God to preserve it until the day of Christ’s return. This verse challenges us to examine the foundation of our own faith. Are we ashamed of the gospel? Do we know whom we have believed? Are we persuaded of God's ability to keep what we have committed to Him? Let us, like Paul, embrace suffering with a steadfast heart, knowing that our faith is rooted in the unwavering power and love of God.

para_meditar.texto: For I am persuaded that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor powers, nor things present, nor things to come, Nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature, shall be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord.
Now faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen.
Being confident of this very thing, that he which hath begun a good work in you will perform it until the day of Jesus Christ:

2027-06-09.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You today with hearts full of gratitude for the steadfastness of faith exemplified by Paul. Help us to embrace his unwavering conviction, even in the face of life's challenges. Grant us the courage to not be ashamed of the Gospel of Jesus Christ, but to boldly proclaim His name in all we do. Lord, we confess that we often struggle with doubt and fear. Strengthen our faith, and help us to fully trust in Your ability to keep all that we commit to You. We surrender our lives, our worries, and our hopes into Your loving hands. Fill us with the Holy Spirit, that we may be persuaded of Your love and power, and that we may live lives worthy of the calling You have placed upon us. Guide us and protect us, until the day we meet You face to face, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2027-06-10.versiculo: Romans 12:15 KJV: "Rejoice with them that do rejoice, and weep with them that weep."
2027-06-10.reflexion: Romans 12:15 calls us to a profound empathy, urging us to connect with others' emotions as if they were our own. This verse transcends mere sympathy; it demands that we participate in the joys and sorrows of those around us. To 'rejoice with them that do rejoice' means to genuinely celebrate their triumphs, to find joy in their accomplishments, and to offer heartfelt congratulations. This requires us to put aside envy, resentment, and self-centeredness, and instead, embrace a spirit of generosity and shared happiness. Similarly, to 'weep with them that weep' asks us to offer comfort and support during times of sorrow. It means being present in their grief, sharing their pain, and providing a shoulder to cry on. This involves vulnerability, as we must allow ourselves to feel the weight of their suffering. It also requires compassion, as we seek to understand their feelings without judgment. In a world often marked by division and indifference, this verse serves as a powerful reminder of our interconnectedness. By practicing this empathy, we build stronger relationships, foster a sense of community, and reflect the heart of God, who weeps with those who weep and rejoices with those who rejoice.

para_meditar.texto: Look not every man on his own things, but every man also on the things of others.
